name: Sfenj (Moroccan Doughnut)
description: Ring-shaped fried dough — lighter and chewier than Western doughnuts. Dipped in sugar or honey with mint tea.
instructions: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, salt. Add warm water.
Knead into very soft sticky dough. Rest 1 hour.
Oil hands. Pull off dough portions.
Stretch into ring shapes.
Fry rings in hot oil until golden (2 min per side).
Drain. Dust with sugar or drizzle honey.

name: Sambusa (Ethiopian)
description: Ethiopian triangular pastry filled with spiced lentils or meat. Crispy, flaky, and perfect for on-the-go eating.
ingredients: Pastry: 2 cups flour, water, oil, salt
Filling: 2 cups cooked lentils, onion, garlic, berbere, turmeric, salt
instructions: Make thin pastry sheets. Cut into strips.
Cook lentil filling with spices.
Shape triangles, fill, seal edges.
Deep fry until crispy golden.
Serve hot.

name: Matoke and Groundnut Sauce
description: Uganda's iconic combo — steamed mashed green bananas topped with thick groundnut (peanut) sauce.
instructions: Peel matoke (in water to avoid stains).
Wrap in banana leaves. Steam 30 min until soft. Mash.
Fry onion in oil. Add tomatoes.
Dissolve peanut paste in water. Add to pot.
Simmer 15 min until thick and creamy.
Serve mashed matoke with groundnut sauce.

name: Derssa
description:
Derssa (Arabic: درسة) is a popular condiment in Algerian cuisine, which is typically made with garlic, cumin, red chili pepper flakes, and olive oil. It is often served alongside grilled or roasted meats, and also used as a marinade for meat or vegetables before cooking. It is a versatile condiment and is often used to add flavor to various dishes, It can also be used as a dipping sauce for bread or vegetables, or as a spread for sandwiches or wraps.
The exact recipe for derssa can vary from region to region or even from household to household, with some variations including additional ingredients such as coriander, lemon juice, or tomato paste.
tags: all articles with dead external links
articles with dead external links from january 2024
articles with permanently dead external links

name: Asida
description: Thick wheat/sorghum porridge shaped into a dome — eaten by hand with stew, a staple in Sudan and South Sudan.
instructions: Boil water.
Add flour gradually, stirring vigorously.
Cook until very thick and smooth.
Shape into a dome on a plate.
Make a well in the centre, fill with stew.
Serve with mulah (stew).

name: Fura da Nono
description: Northern Nigerian milkshake — millet balls crumbled into fermented milk (nono). Refreshing and nutritious.
instructions: Wash and soak millet for a few hours. Drain.
Grind millet with ginger, cloves, and black pepper into a paste.
Form into balls and boil in water until cooked through (20 min).
Remove and let cool.
Crumble fura balls into a bowl of cold nono.
Add sugar or honey to taste.
Mix well and drink cold. Incredibly refreshing.

name: Red Red
description: Ghanaian black-eyed pea stew in palm oil with fried plantain — simple, hearty, and budget-friendly.
instructions: Boil beans until tender.
Heat palm oil, fry onion.
Add blended tomato and pepper. Cook 15 min.
Add cooked beans, salt, and simmer 10 min.
Fry sliced plantain separately.
Serve beans topped with fried plantain.

name: Mbege
description: Mbege is a kind of banana drink traditional to the Chagga ethnic group of Tanzania located in Kilimanjaro region. It is a mildly alcoholic drink made from fermented bananas and finger millet. Making mbege is labor-intensive and time-consuming as the majority of the process is done by hand without the aid of modern technology.
tags: articles needing additional references from august 2011
articles with specifically marked weasel-worded phrases from october 2015

name: Maputi (Popcorn)
description: Zimbabwe's street popcorn — popped in huge pots over open fire, salted, and sold in recycled plastic bags. Cheap joy.
instructions: Heat oil in large covered pot.
Add kernels. Cover. Shake occasionally.
Remove from heat when popping slows.
Salt generously.
Pack into bags.

name: Kelewele
description: Spicy fried plantain cubes seasoned with ginger, chilli, and cloves — Ghana's favourite street snack.
instructions: Peel and dice plantains into cubes.
Mix ginger, chilli, cloves, anise, and salt.
Toss plantain cubes in spice mix. Marinate 10 min.
Deep fry in hot oil until golden and crispy.
Drain and serve hot with roasted peanuts.

name: Moi Moi (Bean Pudding)
description: Steamed bean pudding made from blended peeled beans — soft, savoury, and often stuffed with eggs and fish.
ingredients: Uma (moi moi leaves) or aluminium cups
instructions: Soak beans, remove skins, and blend until smooth with peppers and onion.
Add oil, crayfish, seasoning, and salt. Mix well.
The batter should be pourable but not too thin.
Grease cups or line with leaves. Pour in batter.
Add boiled egg halves or sardines into each cup (optional).
Steam in a pot with water for 40–45 minutes.
Check with a toothpick — it should come out clean.
Serve with jollof rice, custard, or pap.

name: Yaji (spice blend)
description: Yaji is a west African spice blend in Nigeria  common with the hausa people. It is also adopted by other west Africans. It is paired as a spice rub and spice dust for suya and balangu.
tags: short description with empty wikidata description

name: Bunny Chow
description: Hollowed-out bread loaf filled with curry — born in Durban's Indian community. South Africa's iconic street food.
instructions: Cook curry: fry onion, add curry powder, ginger, garlic.
Add meat. Brown all over.
Add tomatoes, potatoes, water. Simmer 30 min.
Cut bread loaf in half or quarter.
Hollow out the centres.
Fill with curry. Replace bread "lid".
Eat with your hands, tearing bread and scooping curry.

name: Gurasa
description: Gurasa is a local bread originating from the Northern part of Nigeria, specifically Kano state. It is similar to bread except the dough is lighter. This local Northern bread is eaten for breakfast, lunch, or as a snack..

name: Kisra (Sudanese Flatbread)
description: Thin, fermented sorghum crepe — Sudan and South Sudan's daily bread, eaten with every stew.
instructions: Mix sorghum flour with water and starter.
Ferment 12–24 hours.
Heat a flat pan (doka).
Pour thin layer of batter, spread in circular motion.
Cook one side until set. Peel off.
Stack and serve with meat, vegetable, or peanut stew.

name: Bazin
description: Libya's national dish — a dome of hardened barley or wheat dough served with a tomato-lamb-egg stew.
instructions: Cook lamb stew with tomato, potato, turmeric, fenugreek.
Boil water, gradually add barley flour.
Stir with a thick stick until very firm.
Shape into a smooth dome with wet hands.
Place bazin dome in centre of stew bowl.
Place eggs around it.
Eat by pinching bazin and dipping into stew.

name: Daraba (Okra Stew)
description: Chadian okra and peanut butter stew — creamy, thick, and served with boule (millet porridge).
instructions: Boil okra until slimy and soft.
Add peanut butter dissolved in warm water.
Add chopped tomatoes and greens.
Simmer 15 min until creamy.
Season with salt.
Serve with boule (millet ball porridge).

name: Ofada Rice & Ayamase Stew
description: Aromatic unpolished local rice served with spicy green pepper stew (ayamase / designer stew) — a Yoruba luxury.
instructions: Wash ofada rice thoroughly in multiple changes of water.
Cook until soft. Drain and set aside.
Boil green peppers and scotch bonnets. Blend coarsely.
Bleach palm oil (heat until it turns clear). Let it cool slightly.
Fry diced onions in the oil until brown.
Add blended pepper mix. Cook until oil floats.
Add iru, crayfish, seasoning, and salt.
Add cooked meat, ponmo, and boiled eggs. Simmer 15 minutes.
Wrap ofada rice in banana leaf (uma). Serve with ayamase.

name: Mafé (Peanut Stew)
description: Rich peanut butter stew with beef or lamb, cooked with tomatoes and root vegetables. Comfort food across West Africa.
instructions: Brown meat in oil with onions.
Add tomato paste, fry 5 min.
Add water to cover, bring to boil.
Dissolve peanut paste in warm water, add to pot.
Add vegetables and pepper. Simmer 40 min.
Stir regularly to prevent sticking.
Serve over white rice.

name: Pap and Chakalaka
description: South Africa's daily staple — maize porridge with spicy vegetable and bean relish. Found at every braai and dinner table.
ingredients: Pap: 2 cups maize meal, water, salt
Chakalaka: 1 can baked beans, 2 carrots, 1 green pepper, 1 onion, 2 tomatoes, chilli, curry powder, oil
instructions: Make pap: boil water, add maize meal, stir 15 min.
Chakalaka: fry onion, add carrots, peppers, tomatoes.
Add curry powder and chilli. Cook 5 min.
Add baked beans. Simmer 10 min.
Serve pap with chakalaka spooned on top.

name: Misir Wot (Red Lentil Stew)
description: Spiced red lentil stew — Ethiopia's staple protein during Orthodox fasting. Earthy, spicy, and comforting on injera.
instructions: Cook onion in oil until deep brown.
Add berbere, garlic, ginger. Cook 5 min.
Add tomato paste and lentils.
Add water. Bring to boil.
Simmer 20 min until lentils dissolve.
Serve on injera.

name: Fried Rice
description: Nigerian-style fried rice loaded with mixed vegetables, liver, and shrimp — a party staple served alongside jollof.
ingredients: 1 cup mixed vegetables (carrots, green beans, peas, sweetcorn)
instructions: Parboil rice until 70% done. Drain and rinse.
Season and fry liver. Cut into small pieces.
Season and stir-fry prawns. Set aside.
Scramble eggs and cut into strips.
Dice all vegetables into small uniform pieces.
Heat oil in a large pan. Fry onions, then add vegetables.
Add the parboiled rice. Stir well.
Season with curry, thyme, seasoning cubes, and salt.
Add liver, prawns, and egg strips. Toss to combine.
Serve alongside jollof rice at parties.

name: Ikokore
description: Ikokore or Ifokore is a water yam pottage or porridge dish among the Yoruba people, popular among the Ijebu. It is made from Dioscorea alata, called Isu Ewura in Yoruba, grated and cooked with ingredients like peppers, onions, and spices. Some of the common ingredients used in making ikokore include: water yam, ata rodo (scotch bonnet) or ata gungun (pepper powder) , any fish from panla to titus, croaker, shawa or catfish, chopped ponmo, chopped liver, chopped beef, goat meat, gizzard, smoked turkey, shrimps, palm oil, ogiri and other seasonings.
tags: short description is different from wikidata

name: Edo black soup
description: Edo black soup also known as omoebe is a Nigerian soup made mainly from three leaves namely scent leaf, uziza leaf and bitter leaf. Other ingredients include beef, onion, crayfish, pepper and palm oil..
tags: short description is different from wikidata

name: Attiéké (Cassava Couscous)
description: Fermented cassava granules — the Ivorian staple served with fried fish, alloco, and onion-tomato salad.
instructions: Steam attiéké until fluffy and warm.
Make salad: mix sliced onion, tomato, pepper, oil, and lemon.
Fry or grill fish.
Serve attiéké on plate with fish and the onion salad.

name: Chikanda (African Polony)
description: Zambian meatless "polony" made from wild orchid tubers and peanuts — a unique vegetarian delicacy.
instructions: Mix chikanda powder with water to a paste.
Dissolve peanut powder in water separately.
Combine both, add chilli, bicarb, and salt.
Pour into a greased tin.
Steam or bake at 180°C for 1 hour.
Cool, slice like polony. Serve cold or warm.

name: Fufu (Akpu)
description: Fermented cassava swallow — smooth, slightly tangy, and stretchy. A staple in Southeast and South-South Nigeria.
instructions: If using fresh: soak cassava for 3 days until fermented, then sieve.
If using flour: mix fufu flour with cold water to a smooth paste.
Bring a pot of water to a boil.
Add the paste and stir vigorously on heat.
Keep stirring until smooth, firm, and stretchy.
Mould into balls.
Serve with egusi, oha, bitter leaf, or ogbono soup.

name: Kelewele
description: Spiced fried plantain cubes — ripe plantain tossed with ginger, chilli, and spices then deep-fried. Ghana's favourite sweet-spicy street snack.
instructions: Peel and dice plantain into cubes.
Mix ginger, cayenne, anise, cinnamon, salt.
Toss plantain cubes in spice mix. Rest 10 min.
Deep fry in batches until caramelised and crispy.
Drain. Serve with roasted peanuts.

name: Mukimo
description: Kikuyu mashed potato, pumpkin leaves, corn, and beans — a vibrant green mash and festive favourite.
instructions: Boil potatoes, corn, and beans until tender.
Boil pumpkin leaves separately. Chop.
Mash everything together until smooth and green.
Season with salt.
Serve with nyama choma or stew.

name: Maraq (dish)
description: Maraq (Arabic: مرق) is a broth dish and originating in Yemen. The dish is common in Oman, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Somalia, Bahrain, and the Eastern Province of Saudi Arabia. It can also be found in Ethiopia, Djibouti, Kenya, and Indonesia..
tags: short description is different from wikidata

name: Ladob (Sweet Banana)
description: Seychellois banana and sweet potato dessert cooked in coconut milk with nutmeg and vanilla.
instructions: Peel and halve bananas. Peel and cube sweet potatoes.
Bring coconut milk to simmer with sugar and vanilla.
Add sweet potatoes first, cook 10 min.
Add bananas, cook 5 more min.
Sprinkle nutmeg. Serve warm or cold.

name: Kolo (Roasted Barley)
description: Dry-roasted barley, chickpeas, and peanuts seasoned with salt — Ethiopia's ancient grab-and-munch snack.
instructions: Dry-roast barley in a pan over medium heat, stirring constantly.
Roast until golden and fragrant (8–10 min).
Separately roast chickpeas and peanuts.
Mix all together. Season with salt.
Serve in paper cones or cups.

name: Zigni (Eritrean Beef Stew)
description: Eritrea's berbere-spiced beef stew — very similar to Ethiopian wat but with its own Eritrean identity. Served on injera.
instructions: Dry-fry onions (no oil) for 20 min until brown.
Add ghee, garlic, and berbere. Fry 5 min.
Add tomato paste and beef.
Add water and simmer 45 min until tender.
Serve on injera.

name: Chikwangue
description: Chikwangue, also known in Cameroon as bobolo and in the Congo River basin language of Lingala as kwanga, is a starchy, fermented-cassava product that is a staple food across Central Africa: the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), the Republic of Congo (RotC), Gabon, Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea. Chikwangue is made by fermenting cassava in water for up to fourteen days, then turning it into a paste and wrapping it in marantaceae leaves for steaming..
tags: culture articles needing translation from french wikipedia

name: Zanzibar Pizza
description: Thin dough folded around meat, egg, cheese, onion, and chilli — a Zanzibari night market classic. Not Italian pizza at all.
instructions: Roll dough paper-thin on oiled surface.
Spread minced meat, crack eggs, add cheese, onion, pepper.
Fold dough edges over filling like an envelope.
Fry on oiled flat griddle until golden each side.
Cut into squares. Serve with chilli sauce.

name: Suya
description: Nigeria's king of street food — thinly sliced beef rubbed with ground peanut spice mix (yaji), skewered and charcoal-grilled. Served with sliced onions, tomatoes, and cabbage.
instructions: Slice beef very thin against the grain.
Coat generously with suya spice and oil. Marinate 1 hr.
Thread onto wooden skewers.
Grill over hot charcoal, turning frequently (10–15 min).
Sprinkle more yaji spice while hot.
Serve on newspaper with sliced onions, tomatoes, cabbage.

name: Koose (Bean Cake) and Koko
description: Ghana's breakfast combo — spiced bean fritters (koose) with spiced millet porridge (Hausa koko).
ingredients: Koose: 2 cups peeled beans, onion, pepper, ginger, salt
Koko: 1 cup millet flour, ginger, cloves, pepper, sugar, water
instructions: Blend beans with onion, pepper, ginger. Beat until fluffy.
Fry spoonfuls in oil until golden brown.
Make koko: dissolve millet flour in cold water.
Pour into boiling water. Stir. Add spices.
Sweeten with sugar.
Serve hot koose with warm koko.

name: Rolex (Chapati Egg Roll)
description: Uganda's most famous street food — a chapati wrapped around fried egg omelette with vegetables. "Rolled Egg" = Rolex.
instructions: Beat eggs with salt.
Make omelette in pan with onion, tomato, cabbage.
Place warm chapati on top of omelette while still in pan.
Flip. Roll tightly.
Wrap in paper and serve.

name: Nigerian Chicken Stew
description: Base of Nigerian cooking — rich, fried tomato and pepper stew with chicken. Goes on everything from rice to yam to bread.
instructions: Season chicken with thyme, curry, seasoning, onion, and salt. Boil until tender.
Fry chicken pieces in oil until golden. Set aside.
Blend tomatoes, tatashe, scotch bonnet, and 1 onion.
In the same oil, fry chopped onion. Add tomato paste.
Pour in blended pepper mix. Fry on medium heat until oil floats (~30 min). This is the key step.
Add bay leaves, curry, thyme, chicken stock, and chicken pieces.
Simmer for 15 minutes.
Serve over rice, yam, plantain, or with bread.

name: Eba (Garri)
description: Cassava flour (garri) mixed with hot water to form a stretchy dough — the quickest and most affordable swallow in Nigeria.
instructions: Boil water in a kettle.
Pour garri into a bowl.
Add hot water gradually while stirring with a wooden spoon.
Stir quickly and firmly until it forms a smooth, stretchy dough.
Mould into a ball.
Serve immediately with any soup of choice.

name: Achu Soup & Fufu
description: Yellow soup made from limestone and palm oil, served with pounded cocoyam. A cherished Northwest dish.
instructions: Boil cocoyam until soft. Pound until smooth and stretchy.
Boil meat with seasoning until tender.
For yellow soup: dissolve limestone in hot water, strain.
Mix palm oil with limestone water vigorously until yellow.
Add meat broth. The soup should be bright yellow and smooth.
Serve fufu in a bowl of yellow soup.

name: Ful (Eritrean Fava Beans)
description: Eritrean-style fava beans with cumin, tomato, and egg — a hearty breakfast favourite.
instructions: Warm beans in a pan.
Add diced tomato, onion, and pepper.
Season with cumin and salt.
Top with fried egg and drizzle of oil.
Serve with bread.

name: Molokhia
description: Egyptian "green soup" — finely chopped jute leaves in garlic broth, served over rice with chicken. Silky and addictive.
ingredients: 500 g molokhia leaves (fresh or frozen, chopped)
instructions: Cook a whole chicken in water for broth. Shred chicken.
Add finely chopped molokhia leaves to hot broth.
Bring to a brief boil — DO NOT overcook.
Make ta'aleya: fry minced garlic and coriander in ghee until golden.
Add sizzling ta'aleya to the molokhia pot.
Serve over white rice with shredded chicken.

name: Sharba Libiya (Libyan Soup)
description: Libyan lamb and tomato soup with orzo pasta — flavoured with cinnamon, turmeric, and mint. An iftar staple.
instructions: Brown lamb with onion.
Add tomato paste, spices, and water.
Simmer 30 min.
Add chickpeas and orzo.
Cook until pasta is done.
Finish with mint and lemon. Serve hot.

name: Piri Piri Chicken
description: Fiery grilled chicken basted in piri piri chilli sauce with coconut and lime — Mozambique's gift to the world.
instructions: Blend chillies, garlic, lime juice, oil, paprika, and salt.
Marinate chicken in half the sauce for 1–4 hours.
Add coconut cream to remaining sauce for basting.
Grill chicken over charcoal, basting frequently.
Cook 15 min each side until charred and juicy.
Serve with matapa and rice.

name: Groundnut Soup (Sierra Leone)
description: Thick peanut soup with chicken and vegetables — a Sierra Leonean comfort classic.
instructions: Boil chicken with onion and seasoning.
Blend tomatoes and add to stock.
Dissolve groundnut paste in warm water, add to pot.
Add okra and pepper. Simmer 25 min.
Stir regularly. Serve over rice.

name: Molokhia
description: Jute leaf soup — slimy, garlicky, and deeply flavourful green stew. Egypt's everyday pharaonic comfort food.
ingredients: 500 g fresh or frozen molokhia leaves (chopped)
instructions: Finely chop molokhia leaves.
Bring broth to boil. Add molokhia.
Fry garlic with coriander in ghee until fragrant.
Pour garlic mixture into soup. Stir.
Serve over rice with chicken or rabbit.

name: Walwal (South Sudan Stew)
description: South Sudanese thick okra stew with meat, peanut butter, and greens — hearty and common in the south.
instructions: Cook meat until tender.
Add sliced okra and greens.
Dissolve peanut paste in water, add to pot.
Simmer 25 min until thick.
Serve with asida or sorghum porridge.

name: Banku and Tilapia
description: Fermented corn-cassava dough ball with grilled tilapia and fresh pepper sauce — Ga-Ewe classic combo.
instructions: Mix corn dough and cassava dough with water.
Cook on medium heat stirring continuously until smooth and ball forms.
Grill tilapia after seasoning.
Make pepper sauce: blend fresh peppers, onion, tomato.
Serve banku ball with tilapia and pepper sauce.

name: Ofe Nsala (White Soup)
description: Igbo white soup — a light, peppery catfish soup thickened with pounded yam, without palm oil.
instructions: Boil catfish with onion, seasoning, and salt for 10 minutes.
Remove fish and set aside.
Dissolve small lumps of pounded yam into the fish stock to thicken it.
Add ground uziza, crayfish, and scotch bonnet.
Return the fish to the pot.
Simmer for 10 minutes.
Add shredded utazi leaves in the last minute.
Serve with pounded yam or fufu.

name: Sodabi
tags: articles needing additional references from march 2019

name: Ampesi (Boiled Yam/Plantain) with Kontomire
description: Boiled yam, plantain, or cocoyam with kontomire (cocoyam leaf) stew. Ghana's simple healthy everyday meal.
ingredients: Kontomire stew: cocoyam leaves, palm oil, tomatoes, onion, smoked fish, agushie (melon seeds)
instructions: Boil yam/plantain in salted water until tender.
Make stew: blend or chop kontomire leaves.
Fry onion in palm oil. Add tomatoes, agushie.
Add leaves and smoked fish. Simmer 15 min.
Serve boiled tuber with kontomire stew.

name: Roasted Corn
description: Fresh corn on the cob roasted over charcoal until slightly charred and smoky. Often paired with roasted coconut or pear (ube).
ingredients: Fresh corn on the cob (in husk)
instructions: Pull back husk partially. Remove silk.
Place directly on hot charcoal.
Turn every 2–3 minutes.
Roast until kernels are charred and smoky (10–15 min).
Eat straight off the cob. Pair with ube (African pear) if in season.

name: Gozo (Cassava Bread)
description: CAR's staple — thick cassava flour bread served with every meal. Dense, filling, and traditional.
instructions: Boil water with salt.
Add cassava flour gradually, stirring.
Cook on low heat 15 min, stirring constantly.
Shape into a thick mound.
Serve with kanda, palm nut sauce, or greens.

name: Vetkoek
description: Deep-fried bread dough — crispy outside, fluffy inside. Eaten with mince, syrup, jam, or cheese. South Africa's doughnut.
instructions: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, salt.
Add warm water to form soft dough.
Knead 5 min. Rise 1 hour.
Shape into balls. Deep fry until golden (3–4 min per side).
Drain on paper. Split open.
Fill with curried mince, jam, or syrup.

name: Puff Puff
description: Deep-fried dough balls — golden, pillowy, and lightly sweetened. Nigeria's most popular street snack, found at every corner.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, salt, yeast, nutmeg.
Add warm water gradually. Mix to thick batter.
Cover and rise 1–2 hours until doubled.
Heat oil to 170°C. Scoop balls of batter into oil.
Fry until golden brown all over (3–4 min).
Drain on paper towels. Serve warm.

name: Garba
description: Attiéké (cassava couscous) with deep-fried tuna, chilli, and onions. Named after a famous Abidjan street vendor.
instructions: Steam or fluff attiéké.
Season tuna and fry until crispy.
Slice onion thinly. Dice pepper.
Serve attiéké with crumbled fried tuna on top.
Garnish with onion rings and pepper.

name: Vetkoek
description: Deep-fried bread dough — crispy outside, fluffy inside. Filled with mince or jam. Afrikaans comfort food.
instructions: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, salt. Add warm water, knead.
Cover, let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Punch down, form into balls.
Deep fry in hot oil until golden (5 min each side).
Drain on paper towel.
Cut open, fill with curried mince or butter and jam.

name: Spaghetti Jollof
description: Spaghetti cooked in peppery tomato sauce — Nigeria's quick weeknight pasta. Student and office-worker favourite.
instructions: Boil spaghetti al dente. Drain.
Blend tomatoes and peppers.
Fry onion in oil. Add blended pepper.
Cook sauce 15 min.
Add spaghetti. Toss to coat.
Add protein of choice.
Serve hot.

name: Ravitoto
description: Pounded cassava leaves with pork — Madagascar's other great dish. Tender greens and rich pork fat.
instructions: Pound cassava leaves until very fine (or use frozen).
Boil leaves 30 min to remove bitterness.
Fry pork pieces until golden.
Add onion, garlic, ginger, tomatoes.
Add the cassava leaves. Simmer 30 min.
Serve with rice and rougail (tomato chutney).

name: Makroud (Semolina Date Cookies)
description: Algerian diamond-shaped semolina pastries stuffed with date paste and dipped in honey — festive sweetness.
instructions: Mix semolina with melted butter and orange blossom water.
Knead to a smooth dough.
Roll into logs. Make a groove, fill with date paste. Close.
Cut into diamond shapes.
Deep fry until golden.
Dip in warm honey. Let cool.

name: Shiro Wat
description: Chickpea flour stew — Ethiopia's most beloved vegan dish. Eaten on fasting days and loved every other day too.
instructions: Fry onions in oil until golden.
Add garlic, tomato, and berbere.
Add water, bring to simmer.
Gradually whisk in shiro powder to avoid lumps.
Stir continuously on low heat 15 min until thick.
Serve on injera.

name: Piri Piri Prawns
description: Giant prawns marinated in fiery piri piri chilli sauce and grilled. Mozambique's most famous street food export.
ingredients: Piri piri sauce: 10 bird's eye chillies, garlic, lemon, paprika, olive oil, vinegar
instructions: Blend chillies, garlic, lemon juice, paprika, oil, vinegar into piri piri sauce.
Marinate prawns in sauce for 30 min.
Grill over very hot charcoal 3 min per side.
Squeeze lemon over.
Serve with rice or bread and cold 2M beer.

name: Dundun (Fried Yam)
description: Crispy fried yam sticks served with pepper sauce or egg sauce — a popular breakfast and street food.
ingredients: Pepper sauce or egg stew for dipping
instructions: Peel yam and cut into thick sticks or rounds.
Soak in salted water for 5 minutes.
Heat oil in a deep pan.
Fry yam pieces in batches until golden brown and crispy.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve with fried egg sauce, pepper sauce, or fried stew.

name: Ewedu Soup
description: Silky jute leaf soup — a Yoruba staple always served with gbegiri and stew on amala.
instructions: Pick ewedu leaves from stems. Wash thoroughly.
Boil with a pinch of potash for 5 minutes until soft.
Use a broom whisk (ijabe) or blender to break down the leaves.
Add locust beans and seasoning. Stir.
Simmer 5 minutes until slimy and smooth.
Serve alongside gbegiri and stew over amala.

name: Plantain Porridge
description: Unripe plantain cooked down in a savoury palm oil and pepper broth — hearty, filling, and nutritious.
instructions: Peel and cut plantains into chunks.
Boil in water until half-tender (about 10 minutes).
Add palm oil, blended pepper, onion, crayfish, and seasoning.
Add smoked fish. Continue cooking until plantain is soft.
Add chopped vegetables in the last 3 minutes.
Serve on its own or with rice.

name: Waakye (Rice and Beans)
description: Ghana's beloved rice & beans combo — cooked with millet stalks for a signature red colour. Served with shito, spaghetti, and protein.
ingredients: Accompaniments: gari, shito, boiled egg, spaghetti, fried fish, fried chicken
instructions: Parboil beans 20 min. Add waakye leaves (wrapped in cloth).
Add rice and salt. Top up water.
Cook until rice and beans are tender and reddish.
Serve on banana leaf with shito, gari, spaghetti, wele, egg, and protein.

name: Jollof Rice
description: Nigeria's pride — smoky one-pot tomato rice cooked to perfection. Party jollof with the bottom-pot "sóòsì" is unmatched.
instructions: Blend tomatoes, tatashe, and scotch bonnets until smooth.
Heat oil in a heavy-bottom pot. Fry diced onion until golden.
Add tomato paste and fry for 2 minutes.
Pour in blended pepper mix. Cook on medium heat, stirring regularly, until oil floats (about 30 minutes).
Add curry, thyme, bay leaves, stock, and salt.
Wash rice thoroughly and add to the pot. Stir once.
Cover tightly with foil, then the lid. Cook on low heat for 30 minutes.
Do NOT open the lid. Let it steam.
Fluff with a fork. Serve with fried plantain and coleslaw.

name: Chin Chin
description: Crunchy fried pastry bites — sweet, addictive, and ever-present at Nigerian celebrations.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, nutmeg, baking powder, and salt.
Rub in butter until mixture resembles breadcrumbs.
Beat eggs with milk. Add to flour mixture.
Knead into a smooth, firm dough.
Roll out on a floured surface and cut into small strips or squares.
Deep fry in batches on medium heat until golden (5–6 minutes).
Drain and cool completely. Store in airtight container.

name: Ful Medames and Bread
description: Egypt's national breakfast — slow-cooked fava beans mashed with olive oil, lemon, cumin, served with pita bread and boiled egg.
instructions: Warm fava beans in pot with some liquid.
Mash partially. Season with cumin, garlic, lemon, olive oil.
Serve in bowls drizzled with more olive oil.
Top with diced tomato, parsley, and tahini.
Serve with warm pita bread and halved boiled eggs.

name: Muboora (Pumpkin Leaves)
description: Shona-style pumpkin leaves cooked with peanut butter — creamy, nutritious, and deeply traditional.
instructions: Wash and shred pumpkin leaves.
Boil in water 10 min until tender.
Add peanut butter, stir to dissolve.
Add diced tomato and onion. Season.
Simmer 10 min until creamy.
Serve with sadza.

name: Brochettes (Rwandan)
description: Charcoal-grilled goat meat skewers — Rwanda's social food, served at every bar and gathering across Kigali.
instructions: Cube goat meat. Season with salt and pepper.
Thread onto wooden skewers.
Grill over charcoal, turning regularly.
Serve with fried plantain, chips, or salad.

name: Rechta
description: Rechta (Arabic: رشتة) is a dish made from pasta cut into thin fresh artisan strips, typical of Algeria. It is in particular the symbolic dish of Algiers cuisine..
tags: articles with unsourced statements from november 2021
short description is different from wikidata

name: Mechoui (Roast Lamb)
description: Whole spit-roasted lamb — a Mauritanian feast dish, slow-cooked over coals until tender and smoky.
instructions: Clean and prep the whole lamb.
Rub with butter, cumin, garlic, paprika, and salt.
Mount on a spit over hot coals.
Roast slowly for 3–4 hours, rotating and basting.
The meat should be fall-off-the-bone tender.
Serve on a large platter with bread and salad.

name: Mahindi Choma (Roasted Corn)
description: Fresh maize cob roasted over charcoal and rubbed with chilli-lime salt. Kenya's favourite roadside snack.
instructions: Place corn directly on hot charcoal.
Turn every 2 min until charred all around.
Squeeze lime over the corn.
Sprinkle with chilli and salt.
Eat immediately.

name: Soya (Cameroonian Suya)
description: Spiced beef skewers grilled over charcoal — Cameroon's most popular street food. Spicier than Nigerian suya.
instructions: Cube beef. Season with white pepper, garlic, ginger, cubeb pepper.
Marinate for 30 min.
Thread onto skewers.
Grill over charcoal, basting with oil.
Serve with raw onion, pepper, and baguette.

name: Funge
description: Angolan cassava flour porridge — smooth, stretchy, and essential alongside any stew.
instructions: Boil water with salt.
Slowly add cassava flour stirring vigorously.
Keep stirring 10 min on low heat until thick and smooth.
Shape with wet spoon.
Serve alongside muamba, calulu, or any stew.

name: Githeri
description: Boiled maize and beans — Kenya's simplest everyday meal. Often upgraded with potatoes, tomatoes, and onion.
instructions: Soak maize and beans overnight.
Boil together until both are tender (about 1 hr).
Fry onion in oil. Add tomatoes.
Add potatoes and cooked maize-beans.
Season and simmer 15 min.
Serve as a complete one-pot meal.

name: Matapa
description: Cassava leaf stew cooked in coconut milk with ground peanuts and prawns — Mozambique's signature dish.
instructions: Pound cassava leaves until smooth (or use frozen).
Boil leaves in water 20 min.
Add coconut milk and ground peanuts. Stir.
Add garlic and onion. Simmer 15 min.
Add prawns last 5 min.
Serve with white rice.

name: Caldou
description:
Caldou, also spelled kaldou, is a traditional dish from Senegal, particularly associated with the coastal regions. It is a broth-based meal primarily prepared with fresh fish and vegetables. The dish shares some visual similarities with the popular Senegalese Yassa, another fish-based dish, but differs significantly in its flavor profile and preparation techniques.
At its core, Caldou is built around the natural flavors of fresh fish, which are simmered in a broth.

articles with dead external links from august 2025
articles with permanently dead external links

name: Wasawasa
description: Wasawasa is a popular dish, eaten in Dagbon and other parts of Northern Ghana. It is also eaten in some West African countries, such as Burkina Faso, Benin, Nigeria etc. It is made from dried yam peelings called jaling, which have been grounded into flour and steamed.
tags: articles lacking reliable references from january 2020
short description is different from wikidata

name: Fah-fah
description:
Fah-fah is a Djiboutian soup, mostly eaten in southern parts of the country, and popular in East African cuisine. Fah-fah is typically made of goat meat with vegetables and green chilies and served with flatbread: aish (Lebanese bread), injera (Ethiopian flatbread), or lahoh (a sponge-like Somali bread).
Fah-fah should not be confused with the dry infant formula faffa from Ethiopia..

name: Braai (South African BBQ)
description: More than a barbecue — it's a way of life. Boerewors, sosaties, lamb chops, and mealies over wood fire.
instructions: Build a wood or charcoal fire. Let coals go white.
Season lamb chops with braai salt. Grill 4 min each side.
Coil boerewors on grid, grill 15 min, turning once.
Grill sosaties and mealies alongside.
Serve with pap, chakalaka, and braai broodjies (toasted sandwiches).

name: Klui-Klui (Peanut Sticks)
description: Beninese fried peanut paste sticks — crunchy, savoury, and a popular snack across the country.
instructions: Grind roasted peanuts to a thick paste.
Add salt, knead until pliable.
Shape into thin sticks or flat discs.
Deep fry in oil until crispy and golden.
Drain and cool. Store in airtight container.

name: Chipsi Mayai (Chips Mayai)
description: Tanzanian omelette loaded with French fries — street food fusion that became a national obsession.
instructions: Fry chips until golden and crispy.
Beat eggs with diced onion, tomato, chilli, and salt.
Pour egg mixture over chips in the pan.
Cook until set, flip once.
Serve hot with chilli sauce and kachumbari.

name: Bofrot (Ghanaian Doughnut)
description: Pillowy fried dough balls, sweeter and denser than puff puff. Ghana's beloved afternoon street snack.
instructions: Mix dry ingredients. Add warm water to form soft dough.
Knead 5 min. Cover and rise 1.5 hours.
Shape into balls.
Deep fry in oil until golden brownish-red (4 min).
Roll in sugar if desired.
Serve warm.

name: Poulet DG (Director General Chicken)
description: Cameroon's ultimate party dish — fried chicken and plantain in a rich tomato-vegetable sauce. Named because only bosses could afford it.
instructions: Season and fry chicken until golden. Set aside.
Fry plantain slices. Set aside.
In same oil, sauté onions, garlic, leeks.
Add diced tomatoes, carrots, and green beans.
Add chicken back. Simmer 15 min.
Fold in fried plantains gently.
Serve hot — true Cameroon luxury.

name: Miyan Kuka (Baobab Soup)
description: Northern Nigerian baobab leaf soup — slightly sour, slimy, and perfect with tuwo shinkafa.
instructions: Cook meat with onion and seasoning until tender. Reserve stock.
Dissolve kuka powder in warm water to a smooth paste.
Bring meat stock to a boil.
Stir in the kuka paste. Mix thoroughly to avoid lumps.
Add dawadawa, pepper, and oil.
Simmer for 10 minutes.
Serve hot over tuwo shinkafa or tuwo masara.

name: Fataya (Senegalese Pastry)
description: Deep-fried stuffed pastries filled with spiced fish or meat — Senegal's beloved street snack.
instructions: Make dough: mix flour, oil, salt, and water. Knead smooth.
Prepare filling: sauté minced fish/meat with onion, parsley, pepper.
Roll dough thin, cut circles.
Place filling and fold into half-moons. Seal edges.
Deep fry until golden brown.
Serve hot with hot sauce.

name: Brik à l'Oeuf
description: Tunisia's legendary appetizer — a thin malsouka pastry shell encasing a runny egg, tuna, capers, and parsley.
instructions: Mix tuna with capers, parsley, and onion.
Lay a sheet of malsouka on work surface.
Place tuna mixture on one side.
Crack an egg on top (careful — it must stay runny).
Fold into a triangle. Seal edges.
Deep fry quickly — 2 min per side.
The egg inside should be barely set.
Serve immediately with lemon and harissa.

name: Cereal and Milk (Nigerian Style)
description: Golden Morn, cornflakes, or custard with evaporated milk — Nigeria's go-to quick breakfast cereal combo.
ingredients: Hot or warm water (for Golden Morn)
instructions: Pour cereal into a bowl.
Add warm water (Golden Morn) or use dry (cornflakes).
Pour evaporated milk over cereal generously.
Add sugar to taste.
Mix and eat immediately.

name: Agege Bread and Ewa Agoyin
description: Soft Agege bread torn and dipped in mashed beans with fiery palm oil pepper sauce — Lagos street food combo.
ingredients: Ata dindin (fried pepper sauce) with palm oil, dried pepper, onion, crayfish, locust beans
instructions: Buy or prepare ewa agoyin (beans mashed smooth).
Make ata dindin: bleach palm oil, fry dried pepper, onion, crayfish, iru.
Tear chunks of soft Agege bread.
Scoop beans onto bread, top with ata dindin.
Eat straight away — this is a Lagos rite of passage.

name: Rice and Beans (Nigerian)
description: Nigeria's classic combo — jollof-style rice cooked together with honey beans. Budget-friendly, filling, and protein-rich.
instructions: Parboil beans for 15 min. Drain.
Blend tomatoes, peppers, onion.
Fry blended pepper in palm oil 10 min.
Add beans and water. Cook 20 min until half done.
Add washed rice. Water should be level with rice.
Season. Cover tightly and cook until done.
Serve with fried plantain (dodo) and stew.

name: Pap en Vleis
description: Maize porridge with meat and tomato gravy — the everyday comfort food of South Africa.
instructions: Boil water with salt. Gradually add maize meal, stirring.
Cook on low heat 20 min, stirring, until stiff.
Fry onions in oil. Add meat, brown.
Add tomatoes, paste, seasoning, splash of water.
Simmer 25 min until meat tender and gravy thick.
Serve pap with meat and gravy.

name: Kilishi
description: Hausa dried meat — thinly sliced beef sun-dried and coated in a spicy groundnut paste. Nigeria's beef jerky.
instructions: Slice beef very thinly against the grain (paper-thin).
Spread on a mesh/rack and sun-dry for a full day.
Mix groundnut paste with all spices, honey, and a little water to form a marinade.
Dip each piece of dried meat into the paste, coating both sides.
Return to the drying rack and sun-dry again for another day.
Finally, grill briefly over low charcoal heat to toast.
Store in airtight container. Lasts for weeks.

name: Pap (Ogi / Akamu)
description: Fermented corn porridge — smooth, tangy, and comforting. The classic Nigerian breakfast, usually paired with akara or moi moi.
instructions: Dissolve ogi paste in a cup with cold water until smooth.
Bring water to a rolling boil.
Pour boiling water into the ogi mixture while stirring continuously.
Stir vigorously — it will thicken and become translucent.
Add sugar/honey and milk to taste.
Serve warm with akara, moi moi, or bread.

name: Nyembwe Chicken
description: Gabon's national dish — chicken simmered in palm nut cream (nyembwe). The pride of Gabonese cuisine.
instructions: Season chicken with garlic and salt. Brown in oil.
Fry onions and tomatoes until soft.
Add palm nut cream. Mix well.
Return chicken. Add water to cover.
Simmer 40 min until chicken is cooked through.
Sauce should be thick, creamy, and orange.
Serve with plantain, rice, or cassava sticks (bâton de manioc).

name: Riz au Gras (Guinea)
description: Guinea's one-pot "fatty rice" — cooked in a meaty tomato broth with vegetables. Their version of jollof.
instructions: Brown meat in oil. Set aside.
Fry onions, add tomato paste.
Add water, vegetables, and meat.
When vegetables are done, add washed rice.
Cook covered until rice absorbs all liquid.
Serve with extra pepper sauce.

name: Sishwala
description: Eswatini thick sour porridge made from fermented mealie meal — tangy and traditionally served with stew.
instructions: Ferment mealie meal with water for 1–2 days.
Cook fermented mixture stirring constantly.
Add more meal to thicken if needed.
Cook until stiff and slightly sour.
Serve with meat stew or vegetables.

name: Brochettes (Rwandan Meat Skewers)
description: Charcoal-grilled goat meat skewers — Rwanda's favourite evening street food, best with a cold Primus beer.
instructions: Thread goat meat onto skewers.
Season with salt.
Grill over charcoal until cooked and slightly charred.
Serve with fried plantains and chilli sauce.

name: Fataya (Senegalese Meat Pie)
description: Crispy half-moon pastry stuffed with spiced fish or meat. Senegal's street food staple sold at every corner.
ingredients: Dough: 3 cups flour, water, oil, salt
Filling: 300 g fish or beef, onion, parsley, garlic, lemon, mustard, pepper, oil
instructions: Make dough. Knead and rest 30 min.
Filling: flake cooked fish. Mix with fried onion, parsley, garlic, lemon, mustard.
Roll dough thin. Cut circles.
Fill, fold into half-moons, seal edges with fork.
Deep fry until golden and crispy.
Serve hot with chilli sauce.

name: Mutura (Kenyan Sausage)
description: African blood sausage — intestine casing stuffed with spiced mince, blood, and herbs then roasted over charcoal. Kenya's grillmaster snack.
instructions: Clean intestines thoroughly. Turn inside out, scrub, rinse.
Mix mince, blood, garlic, ginger, coriander, chilli, salt.
Stuff mixture into intestines. Tie ends.
Smoke or boil first, then grill over charcoal until crispy.
Slice into rounds.
Serve with kachumbari (tomato-onion salsa).

name: Fufu and Pondu
description: Cassava fufu with pounded cassava leaf stew — the DRC's daily meal. Eaten for lunch and dinner across the country.
ingredients: Pondu: 1 kg pounded cassava leaves, palm oil, dried fish, onion, garlic, salt
instructions: Boil water. Add cassava flour stirring vigorously for 10 min.
Pondu: boil pounded leaves 30 min until dark.
Add palm oil, dried fish, onion, garlic.
Simmer 30 min more.
Shape fufu into ball. Serve with pondu.

name: Pounded Yam
description: The king of swallow — smooth, stretchy yam dough pounded in a mortar until cloud-soft. The ultimate Nigerian comfort food.
instructions: Peel yam and cut into medium chunks.
Boil in water until very soft (fork-tender).
Drain most water. Begin pounding in a mortar with a pestle.
Pound continuously, adding small splashes of water, until smooth and stretchy.
Alternatively, use a yam pounder machine.
Mould into smooth balls.
Serve with egusi, efo riro, ogbono, or ofe nsala.

name: Chapman
description: Nigeria's signature cocktail (non-alcoholic version) — a fizzy, fruity mix of Fanta, Sprite, grenadine, and bitters with cucumber and orange.
instructions: In a large pitcher, combine Fanta and Sprite.
Add grenadine syrup and Angostura bitters.
Squeeze in lemon juice.
Add orange and cucumber slices.
Stir gently.
Add Ribena for deeper colour (optional).
Serve over plenty of ice in tall glasses.
Garnish with cucumber and orange slices.

name: Couscous and Lamb Tagine
description: Morocco's Friday classic — fluffy steamed couscous with slow-cooked lamb and seven vegetable tagine.
instructions: Brown lamb with onion in olive oil.
Add spices, tomato paste, water. Simmer 45 min.
Add carrots, turnip, pumpkin. Cook 20 min.
Add zucchini, chickpeas, cabbage. Cook 15 min more.
Steam couscous: moisten, steam, fluff (3 times).
Mound couscous. Top with meat and vegetables. Ladle broth.

name: Kilishi
description: Nigerian beef jerky — sun-dried spiced beef sheets, thin as paper. Hausa specialty often called Africa's biltong.
instructions: Slice beef paper-thin. Sun-dry on wire mesh for 4–6 hours.
Make paste: groundnut paste, spices, ginger, garlic, pepper.
Coat dried beef sheets with the paste.
Sun-dry again for 2–3 hours.
Roast briefly over charcoal fire.
Store in airtight container. Lasts weeks.

name: Maghrebi mint tea
description:
Maghrebi mint tea (Maghrebi Arabic: أتاي, atay; Arabic: الشاي بالنعناع, romanized: aš-šhāy bin-na'nā'), also known as Moroccan mint tea and Tunisian mint tea or Algerian mint tea, is a North African preparation of gunpowder green tea with spearmint leaves and sugar.
It is traditional to the Greater Maghreb region (the northwest African countries of Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya, and Mauritania). Its consumption has spread throughout North Africa, parts of the Sahel, France, Spain, the Arab world, and Middle East.
Mint tea is central to social life in the Maghreb and is very popular among the Tuareg people of Algeria, Libya, Niger and Mali. The serving can take a ceremonial form, especially when prepared for a guest.
