name: Mwambe (Palm Butter Sauce)
description: Palm butter sauce with chicken or fish — shared heritage across both Congos. Rich and orange-hued.
instructions: Brown chicken in oil. Set aside.
Fry onions, garlic, tomatoes.
Add palm butter and water. Stir until smooth.
Return chicken. Simmer 30 min.
Add chilli. Check consistency — should be rich and thick.
Serve with fufu, rice, or boiled cassava.

name: Maakouda (Potato Fritters)
description: Crispy fried potato patties stuffed in bread — Morocco's budget-king street snack. Cheap and filling.
instructions: Mash boiled potatoes. Add eggs, parsley, cumin, salt.
Mix well. Shape into flat patties.
Deep fry until golden brown each side.
Serve in bread with harissa and olives.

name: Isi Ewu (Goat Head)
description: Igbo spiced goat head delicacy — tender meat in a creamy, peppery palm oil sauce with utazi leaves.
instructions: Clean goat head thoroughly. Cut into serving pieces.
Boil with onion and seasoning until very tender.
Mix palm oil with strained potash water. Stir until yellow and thick.
Add ehuru, crayfish, and blended pepper.
Add the tender goat head pieces. Mix well.
Simmer for 10 minutes to absorb flavours.
Garnish with thinly sliced utazi leaves.
Serve in a traditional wooden bowl.

name: Ndolé
description: Cameroon's national dish — bitter leaves cooked with groundnuts, shrimp, and beef in a rich, earthy stew.
instructions: Wash bitter leaves repeatedly to remove bitterness. Boil and squeeze dry.
Cook beef until tender.
Roast and grind groundnuts to paste.
Fry onion and garlic in palm oil.
Add groundnut paste, meat stock, shrimp, and crayfish.
Add bitter leaves and cooked meat.
Simmer 30 min until thick and flavours meld.
Serve with plantain, miondo, or rice.

name: Shiro Wot
description: Chickpea flour stew cooked with berbere, garlic, and onion — Ethiopia's most eaten everyday dish, especially during fasting days.
instructions: Slowly cook onion in oil without browning (30 min).
Add berbere, garlic, ginger. Cook 5 min.
Dissolve shiro in water. Pour into pot.
Stir continuously on medium 10 min.
Adjust thickness. Season.
Serve on injera.

name: Yam and Egg Sauce
description: Fried yam (dundun) or boiled yam served with peppered egg sauce — a beloved Nigerian breakfast/brunch combo.
instructions: Peel yam, slice into rounds. Soak in salted water.
Deep fry yam until golden, or boil until tender.
For sauce: chop tomatoes, onion, peppers.
Fry onion in oil. Add tomatoes and peppers. Cook 5 min.
Crack eggs into sauce. Stir gently to create chunks.
Season. Serve sauce over yam.

name: Okpa
description: Steamed Bambara nut pudding from Enugu — protein-rich, smooth, and wrapped in banana leaves.
instructions: Mix okpa flour with warm water to a smooth batter.
Add palm oil, blended pepper, onion, crayfish, seasoning, and salt.
Mix thoroughly until well combined.
Pour into banana leaves or nylon bags. Tie securely.
Steam in a pot of boiling water for 40 minutes.
Check that it's firm when done.
Unwrap and serve warm with pap or on its own.

name: Romazava
description: Madagascar's national dish — beef and leafy green stew with garlic, ginger, and tomatoes. Served with rice, always.
instructions: Brown beef in oil. Add onion, garlic, ginger.
Add tomatoes. Cook 5 min.
Add water. Simmer 30 min until beef tender.
Add mixed greens last 5 min.
Serve over white rice (vary amin'anana).

name: Tibs (Sautéed Meat)
description: Pan-fried cubed beef or lamb with peppers, onions, and rosemary — the go-to quick Ethiopian meat dish.
instructions: Heat niter kibbeh in a hot pan.
Add meat cubes, sear on high heat.
Add onions, peppers, garlic.
Add rosemary and seasoning.
Stir-fry 10 min.
Serve on injera or with bread (ambasha).

name: Kenkey and Fried Fish
description: Fermented corn dough with grilled tilapia and hot pepper sauce (shito) — Ghana's iconic combo.
instructions: Buy or prepare kenkey.
Fry or grill whole tilapia until crispy.
Slice onions, tomatoes, fresh pepper on a plate.
Serve kenkey with fish, shito, and fresh accompaniments.

name: Kikomando
description: Chopped chapati pieces mixed with beans sauce — the cheapest and most beloved student street food in Uganda.
instructions: Cut chapati into bite-sized pieces.
Pour hot bean stew over chapati pieces.
Mix together.
Add chilli sauce to taste.
Eat straight from the plate.

name: Attiéké and Fried Fish
description: Côte d'Ivoire's everyday combo — fermented cassava couscous with crispy fried fish, onions, and chilli.
instructions: Steam attiéké if dried, or use fresh.
Season and fry whole fish until golden and crispy.
Make alloco-style onion-pepper garnish.
Plate attiéké mound. Fish alongside.
Top with onion rings, tomato slices, and pepper.

name: Gizdodo
description: Gizzard + dodo combo — fried plantain and spiced gizzard tossed in a pepper sauce. A modern Nigerian party favourite.
instructions: Boil gizzards with seasoning until tender. Cut into halves.
Peel and slice plantains. Fry until golden. Set aside.
Dice bell pepper and onion.
Heat oil. Fry onions, add diced peppers and blended scotch bonnet.
Add gizzards, curry, thyme, and seasoning. Toss well.
Fold in the fried plantain gently.
Serve hot as a side dish or small chop.

name: Pastilla (B'stilla)
description: The crown jewel of Moroccan pastry — layers of warqa dough filled with pigeon/chicken, almonds, and cinnamon, dusted with sugar.
instructions: Cook chicken in onion, spices, herbs, and saffron broth.
Shred meat. Reduce broth. Add beaten eggs to broth (scramble lightly).
Fry almonds, grind with cinnamon and sugar.
Layer buttered warqa sheets in a pan.
Layer: egg mixture, shredded meat, almond mixture.
Fold warqa over, add top layers, brush with butter.
Bake until golden and crispy.
Dust with cinnamon and powdered sugar.

name: Jollof Rice (Ghana)
description: Ghanaian jollof — fragrant, tomato-based, and cooked with basmati rice for a drier, more separated grain. The eternal rival of Nigerian jollof.
instructions: Blend tomatoes, peppers, and 1 onion smooth.
Heat oil, fry sliced onion. Add tomato paste, fry 2 min.
Add blended mix 30 min until reduced and oil floats.
Add stock, spices, and washed rice.
Cover tightly, cook low heat 30 min. Do not stir.
Fluff and serve with shito, fried plantain, and chicken.

name: Samosa (Kenyan)
description: Crispy triangular pastry stuffed with spiced minced meat or vegetables. East Africa's ultimate tea-time street snack.
ingredients: Wrappers: 2 cups flour, water, oil, salt
Filling: 300 g minced beef, onion, garlic, cilantro, cumin, chilli, peas, salt
instructions: Make thin pastry. Cut into strips.
Brown mince with onion, garlic, spices, peas.
Form pastry into cone. Fill with mince.
Seal with flour-paste.
Deep fry until golden and crispy.
Serve with tamarind chutney.

name: Romazava
description: Madagascar's national stew — beef with mixed leafy greens (brèdes). Served over rice three times a day.
instructions: Brown beef with onion, garlic, ginger.
Add tomatoes. Cook 5 min.
Add water. Simmer 20 min until tender.
Add mixed greens. Cook 5 more min.
Serve over white rice (vary).

name: Pepper Soup
description: Fiery, aromatic broth made with goat meat, catfish, or assorted meat — Nigeria's favourite cold-weather cure.
instructions: Wash and season meat/fish with salt and seasoning.
Add to a pot with water, onion, garlic, and ginger.
Boil until meat is tender (about 30 minutes for goat meat).
Add pepper soup spice and scotch bonnets.
Simmer for 10 more minutes.
Add torn scent leaves and utazi in the last minute.
Serve hot in a bowl. Perfect with chilled drinks.

name: Taameya (Egyptian Falafel)
description: Egyptian falafel made with fava beans (not chickpeas!) — bright green inside, crispy outside. Superior falafel.
instructions: Soak fava beans 24 hours. DO NOT cook. Drain.
Blend beans with herbs, onion, garlic, and spices.
Add baking powder. Mix well.
Shape into flat patties. Dip in sesame seeds.
Deep fry until golden and crispy (green inside).
Serve in baladi bread with tahini, salad, and pickles.

name: Thiéboudienne (Mauritania)
description: Mauritanian fish and rice — similar to Senegalese version but with local Saharan spice touches.
instructions: Stuff fish with herb paste, fry until golden.
Fry onion and tomato paste.
Add water and vegetables. Simmer 20 min.
Remove veg and fish. Add rice to broth.
Cook covered until rice is tender.
Arrange rice, fish, and vegetables on platter.

name: Msemen and Mint Tea
description: Morocco's breakfast ritual — flaky square-shaped flatbread with sweet mint tea. Dip msemen in honey or cheese.
ingredients: Msemen: 3 cups flour, semolina, butter, oil, salt, water
Tea: Chinese gunpowder green tea, fresh mint, sugar, water
instructions: Make dough with flour, semolina, salt, water. Knead well.
Divide into balls. Flatten thin, fold into squares.
Cook on griddle with butter until golden each side.
Tea: boil water with tea leaves. Add mint and lots of sugar.
Pour from height for froth.
Serve msemen hot with honey, butter, or Laughing Cow cheese alongside tea.

name: Boule (Millet Ball)
description: Chad's staple — stiff millet porridge formed into a ball. Eaten by tearing pieces and dipping in stew.
instructions: Boil water. Gradually add millet flour.
Stir vigorously with a wooden stick.
Cook 15 min until very thick and smooth.
Shape into a round ball with wet hands.
Serve with daraba, meat sauce, or dried fish stew.

name: Puff Puff (Cameroonian)
description: Cameroonian puff puff — fried dough balls often flavoured with nutmeg, sold in little plastic bags at roadside stalls.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, yeast, nutmeg.
Add warm water. Mix to thick batter.
Cover and rise 1 hr.
Fry spoonfuls in hot oil until golden.
Drain. Serve in bags.

name: Bunny Chow
description: Durban's iconic street food — a hollowed-out bread loaf filled with fiery curry. Indian South African soul food.
instructions: Cook onions in oil. Add curry powder, turmeric, curry leaves.
Add meat, brown all sides. Add tomatoes.
Add potatoes, chickpeas, and water to cover.
Simmer 40 min until meat is tender and gravy thick.
Cut bread loaf into quarters. Hollow out each quarter.
Fill with curry. Top with scooped bread as a lid.
Eat with your hands, tearing bread and scooping curry.

name: Amiwo
description: Amiwo is a traditional dish in Benin, consisting of a savory pudding made from spices (onions, garlic, black pepper, salt), cornflour and tomato paste, cooking oil or more traditionally palm oil. It is often served as a side with fried or grilled chicken or fish and a fresh tomato and onion relish. It literally translates to fat pudding..

name: Dibi (Grilled Lamb)
description: Charcoal-grilled marinated lamb, sliced and served with mustard-onion sauce on paper. Senegal's favourite late-night street food.
instructions: Marinate lamb in mustard, lemon, garlic, pepper for 1 hr.
Grill over very hot charcoal, turning regularly.
Slice onions into rings. Mix with mustard and lemon.
Slice grilled lamb into pieces.
Serve on paper with onion-mustard sauce and bread.

name: Peppered Gizzard
description: Tender chicken gizzards in a spicy bell pepper sauce — a popular small chop and bar snack.
instructions: Boil gizzards with onion, curry, thyme, and seasoning until tender.
Dice bell peppers and onions.
Heat oil. Fry onions until golden.
Add diced pepper and blended scotch bonnet. Fry 5 minutes.
Add cooked gizzards and toss.
Season to taste. Cook 5 more minutes.
Serve as a snack, small chop, or side dish.

name: Couscous Royale
description: Morocco's Friday dish — steamed semolina couscous with seven vegetables, lamb, and a rich broth. A sacred tradition.
ingredients: Carrots, turnips, zucchini, pumpkin, cabbage, onions, chickpeas
instructions: Cook meat in a couscoussier base with onion, tomato, and spices.
Add vegetables in stages (hardest first).
Steam couscous over the stew 3 times, breaking up between each steaming.
Fluff final couscous with butter.
Mound couscous on platter, arrange meat and veg.
Ladle broth into a bowl on the side.
Serve family-style.

name: Fisherman Soup
description: South-South seafood extravaganza — a rich, peppery broth teeming with fresh fish, prawns, crabs, and periwinkle.
instructions: Clean and cut catfish. Season with salt.
Boil crabs and periwinkle separately.
In a pot, heat palm oil. Add onion and pepper.
Add crayfish and seasoning. Fry 5 minutes.
Add water/stock and bring to a boil.
Add fish, crabs, prawns, and periwinkle.
Simmer gently for 15–20 minutes.
Add scent leaves in the last minute.
Serve with white rice or eba.

name: Vitumbuwa (Zambian Fritters)
description: Sweet banana fritters — mashed banana mixed into dough and deep-fried. Zambia's sweet street treat.
instructions: Mash bananas. Mix with flour, sugar, yeast.
Add warm water to form thick batter.
Rest 30 min.
Fry spoonfuls in hot oil until golden.
Drain. Serve warm.

name: Gatsby Sandwich
description: Cape Town's monster sandwich — a long roll stuffed with chips, steak, masala sauce, and salad. One feeds four.
instructions: Cook chips until golden and crispy.
Slice and fry steak strips with masala.
Cut roll lengthwise, leaving one side attached.
Layer chips, steak, atchar, lettuce, tomato.
Wrap in paper, cut into portions to share.

name: Dumboy (Liberian Fufu)
description: Pounded fermented cassava — Liberia's version of fufu, stretchy and served with palm butter or pepper soup.
instructions: Boil fermented cassava until very soft.
Pound in a mortar until smooth and elastic.
Shape into balls with wet hands.
Serve with palm butter soup or pepper soup.

name: Katogo
description: Green bananas cooked with beans, groundnuts, or offal in a one-pot stew — Buganda's traditional everyday breakfast.
instructions: Peel and cube green bananas.
Fry onion and tomato.
Add beans or offal and water.
Add bananas. Simmer 25 min until all soft.
Season.
Serve as a hearty breakfast.

name: Ugali na Nyama
description: Tanzania's daily sustenance — stiff maize porridge with meat stew. The nation's favourite combination.
instructions: Cook meat stew: fry onion, add beef, tomatoes, chilli, and water.
Simmer until meat is tender and sauce thickens.
For ugali: boil water, add maize flour gradually, stir hard.
Cook until very firm. Mould.
Serve ugali with meat stew.

name: Nshima with Ifisashi
description: Zambia's daily staple — thick maize porridge (nshima) with peanut-sauced greens (ifisashi).
instructions: Boil water, gradually add mealie meal stirring constantly.
Cook 15 min until very thick and pulls from sides.
For ifisashi: boil greens until tender.
Add peanut powder, tomato, onion. Stir.
Simmer 10 min until creamy.
Shape nshima into balls. Serve with ifisashi.

name: Bread and Egg (Nigerian)
description: Nigeria's universal breakfast — sliced bread with scrambled or fried egg, tomatoes, and pepper. Every Nigerian knows this.
instructions: Heat oil in pan. Fry onion and tomato.
Add diced pepper. Cook 2 min.
Crack eggs into pan. Scramble with veggies.
Season with salt and seasoning cube.
Toast or fry bread slices.
Serve egg on bread or as sandwich. Add tea.

name: Wali na Maharage
description: Tanzania's rice and beans combo — coconut rice served with red beans in coconut sauce. Coastal Swahili flavours.
instructions: Cook rice in coconut milk with turmeric and salt.
Fry onion and garlic. Add tomatoes.
Add cooked beans and coconut milk.
Simmer 15 min until thick.
Serve coconut rice with bean stew.

name: Luwombo (Banana Leaf Stew)
description: Royal Buganda stew — chicken, beef, or groundnut wrapped in banana leaves and slow-steamed. Uganda's court food.
instructions: Mix meat with tomatoes, onions, mushrooms, peppers, and groundnut paste.
Soften banana leaves over heat.
Place mixture in banana leaves, wrap tightly.
Tie securely with banana fibre.
Steam in a pot for 1.5 hours.
Unwrap carefully. Serve with matooke or rice.

name: Mbika (Pumpkin Seed Stew)
description: Congo-Brazzaville pumpkin seed paste stew — thick, nutty, and served with smoked fish and fufu.
instructions: Dissolve ground pumpkin seeds in warm water.
Fry onions in palm oil. Add tomatoes.
Add pumpkin seed paste. Stir.
Add shredded smoked fish and chilli.
Simmer 20 min until thick.
Serve with fufu or boiled plantains.

name: Fufu & Peanut Soup (Togo)
description: Togolese fufu with a thick, fragrant peanut soup loaded with chicken — the nation's comfort food.
instructions: Boil yam/cassava, pound into smooth fufu.
Cook chicken in tomato broth.
Add peanut paste dissolved in water.
Simmer 20 min until thick.
Serve fufu in peanut soup.

name: Tuwo Shinkafa
description: Northern Nigerian rice pudding — soft, smooth, and moulded into balls. The rice version of swallow, served with miyan kuka or taushe.
instructions: Wash rice and boil with plenty of water until overcooked and mushy.
Mash the rice vigorously with a wooden spoon until smooth and stretchy.
Alternatively, mix rice flour with water and stir over heat.
Keep stirring until it forms a thick, smooth dough.
Mould into balls with a wet spoon.
Serve with miyan kuka, taushe, or miyan kubewa.

name: Ndizi Nyama (Plantain & Meat)
description: Tanzanian green banana stew with beef — hearty, thick, and popular in the northern highlands.
instructions: Peel green bananas, soak in salted water.
Brown beef with onions and garlic.
Add tomatoes, cook 10 min.
Add bananas and coconut milk.
Simmer until bananas are tender (25 min).
Season and serve.

name: Pâte Noire & Sauce Gombo
description: Dark fermented corn paste (similar to amala) served with sticky okra sauce — Benin's daily staple.
instructions: Boil water. Stir in fermented corn flour gradually.
Stir until thick and smooth. Shape into mounds.
Cook chopped okra with palm oil, crayfish, and meat.
Serve pâte noire with gombo sauce.

name: Ful Medames
description: Slow-cooked fava beans mashed with olive oil, lemon, and cumin — Egypt's daily breakfast, eaten by millions every morning.
instructions: Heat beans with liquid.
Mash partially. Season with cumin, garlic, lemon, olive oil.
Serve in bowls with more olive oil drizzled on top.
Eat with warm pita bread and boiled eggs.

name: Cachupa
description: Cabo Verde's national dish — a slow-cooked stew of corn, beans, and meat/fish. Cachupa Rica is the festive version.
instructions: Soak corn and beans overnight.
Boil corn and beans until tender (1+ hour).
Add meats, sausage, and root vegetables.
Add cabbage, garlic, bay leaves.
Simmer until everything is tender and stew is thick.
Season well. Serve hot.
Leftover cachupa is fried for breakfast (Cachupa Refogada).

name: Lahoh
description:
Lahoh (Arabic: لحوح, romanized: laḥūḥ [laħuːħ]; Somali: laxoox) is a type of spongy flatbread eaten regularly in Yemen, Djibouti, Kenya, Ethiopia, Somalia and Saudi Arabia. Yemenite Jewish immigrants popularized the dish in Israel. It is called  canjeero/canjeelo in southern Somalia and called lahoh in Somaliland, Djibouti, Yemen and Saudi Arabia.

.
tags: articles with unsourced statements from november 2025

name: Tô (Millet Porridge)
description: Thick millet or sorghum porridge — the staple starch of Mali, served with various sauces.
instructions: Boil water in a pot.
Slowly add millet flour while stirring.
Stir vigorously to avoid lumps.
Cook on low heat until very thick and smooth.
Serve with peanut sauce, okra sauce, or leaf sauce.

name: Smen
description:
Smen (from Arabic: سمن or سمنة also called sman, semn, semneh, or sminn) is a salted, fermented butter native to North African cuisine (Algeria, Morocco and Tunisia), as well as a traditional Yemeni dish. In countries like Jordan and Lebanon, samneh is a type of butter similar to clarified butter, while north African smen is a type of fermented butter similar to ghee.
Smen is an important ingredient in Middle Eastern cuisine and North African cooking. It is produced using butter made from the milk of sheep, goats or a combination of the two.
tags: articles needing additional references from december 2020
articles with unsourced statements from november 2025
cs1 maint: doi inactive as of december 2025
short description is different from wikidata

name: Kat Kat Banane
description: Seychellois green banana curry in coconut milk — Creole comfort food from the Indian Ocean.
instructions: Peel and slice bananas.
Fry onion, garlic, ginger.
Add turmeric and cinnamon.
Add coconut milk and bananas.
Simmer 20 min until bananas are tender.
Serve with rice or grilled fish.

name: Nkwobi
description: Igbo delicacy of spicy cow foot in a thick palm oil and utazi sauce — the king of Nigerian bar snacks.
instructions: Boil cow foot with seasoning until very tender (pressure cooker recommended).
Mix palm oil with dissolved potash water and stir vigorously until it thickens and turns yellow.
Add ground ehuru, crayfish, and blended pepper to the palm oil mix.
Add the cooked cow foot. Toss to coat.
Adjust seasoning.
Garnish with sliced utazi leaves and ugba.
Serve in a wooden mortar bowl for the authentic experience.

name: Akara (Bean Cakes)
description: Deep-fried spiced black-eyed pea fritters — crispy outside, fluffy inside. The original West African falafel.
instructions: Soak and peel beans.
Blend with onion and pepper — no water.
Beat with wooden spoon until airy and fluffy.
Season with salt.
Drop spoonfuls into hot oil (170°C).
Fry until deep golden (3–4 min per side).
Drain. Serve hot with bread or pap.

name: Merguez
description: Spicy lamb sausage with harissa — grilled until bursting and served in a baguette. North Africa's sausage king.
instructions: Grill merguez over charcoal or pan-fry until cooked and slightly charred.
Split baguette. Add lettuce, tomato, onion.
Place sausages inside.
Drizzle with harissa sauce.
Serve immediately.

name: Puff Puff
description: Deep-fried dough balls — pillowy, sweet, and irresistible. Nigeria's answer to doughnuts.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, yeast, nutmeg, and salt.
Add warm water gradually and mix to a smooth, thick batter.
Cover and let rise in a warm place for 1–2 hours until doubled.
Heat oil to 350°F.
Scoop batter with wet hands or a spoon and drop into oil.
Fry, turning occasionally, until golden all over (3–4 minutes).
Drain on paper towels. Dust with powdered sugar (optional).
Serve warm.

name: Eru Soup
description: Southwest Cameroonian soup of shredded eru and waterleaf, loaded with crayfish and cow skin — thick and satisfying.
instructions: Blanch waterleaf until reduced. Squeeze out water.
Cook cow skin and stockfish until tender.
Heat palm oil in pot.
Add crayfish, seasoning, meat, and stock.
Add waterleaf, cook 10 min.
Add shredded eru last. Stir and cook 5 min only.
Serve with garri (fufu corn) or miondo.

name: Thiéboudienne (Rice and Fish)
description: Senegal's national dish combo — broken rice, stuffed fish, and vegetables simmered in tomato sauce.
instructions: Stuff fish with parsley-pepper paste. Fry until golden.
Make base: fry onions, add tomato paste, cook 10 min.
Add vegetables and fish. Cover with water. Simmer 30 min.
Remove fish and veg. Cook rice in the flavoured broth.
Mound rice. Arrange fish and vegetables on top.
Serve communally on a large platter.

name: Nyama Choma (Roast Meat)
description: Kenya's beloved charcoal-grilled goat meat — a social event more than a meal. Best enjoyed with friends and cold Tusker.
instructions: Season goat meat simply with salt.
Grill slowly over charcoal for 45–60 min.
Turn occasionally. Baste with lemon juice.
Meat should be smoky and tender.
Slice and serve with kachumbari and ugali.

name: Riz Gras (Burkina)
description: Burkina Faso's "fat rice" — one-pot rice with meat, tomatoes, and vegetables. The country's comfort food.
instructions: Brown meat in oil. Set aside.
Fry onions, add tomato paste.
Add water, vegetables, and meat back.
Add washed rice. Cook covered until done.
Serve hot.

name: Amala
description: Dark, smooth yam flour swallow — the Yoruba answer to pounded yam. Served with ewedu, gbegiri, and stew (abula).
instructions: Boil water in a pot.
Reduce heat. Gradually pour amala flour into the water while stirring with a wooden spatula.
Stir vigorously to prevent lumps.
Keep stirring on low heat until the mixture is smooth and firm.
Mould into a round shape.
Serve with ewedu + gbegiri + stew (abula) or any Nigerian soup.

name: Fufu (Congolese)
description: Central Africa's staple dough — cassava flour pounded until smooth and stretchy. The base of every meal.
instructions: Boil water with a pinch of salt.
Gradually add cassava flour, stirring vigorously.
Beat with a wooden spoon until smooth and elastic.
Cook 10 min on low, stirring constantly.
Shape into balls with wet hands.
Serve alongside moambe, pondu, or any stew.

name: Rfissa
description: Shredded msemen flatbread layered with lentils and chicken in a fenugreek-spiced broth — served to new mothers.
instructions: Cook chicken with onion, spices, and saffron.
Cook lentils separately.
Shred msemen into pieces.
Layer shredded bread, lentils, and chicken.
Pour rich broth over everything.
Serve hot — traditionally for postpartum recovery.

name: Chicken Tagine with Preserved Lemons & Olives
description: Morocco's most iconic dish — slow-cooked chicken with preserved lemons and olives in a conical clay pot.
instructions: Marinate chicken with grated onion, garlic, ginger, saffron, oil.
Place in tagine pot with marinade and water.
Cook on low 45 min, turning once.
Add preserved lemon pieces and olives.
Cook 15 more min.
Garnish with fresh coriander.
Serve with Moroccan bread or couscous.

name: Fouti (Fonio Porridge)
description: Steamed fonio grain — Guinea's ancient supergrain, served with any sauce. Gluten-free and nutritious.
instructions: Wash fonio thoroughly.
Steam in a couscoussier for 10 min.
Break up clumps, sprinkle with water.
Steam again for 10 min until fluffy.
Fluff with butter/oil and salt.
Serve with peanut sauce or leaf sauce.

name: Ful Medames (Sudan)
description: Sudan's breakfast of champions — slow-cooked fava beans topped with cheese, egg, oil, and bread. A cross-border favourite.
instructions: Warm beans. Mash slightly.
Top with crumbled cheese, fried egg.
Drizzle with sesame oil and lemon.
Season with cumin.
Serve with fresh bread.

name: Mafé (Peanut Stew)
description: Rich peanut butter stew with beef or chicken and root vegetables — West Africa's everyday comfort food.
instructions: Brown meat. Add onion.
Add tomato paste and tomatoes. Cook 10 min.
Dissolve peanut butter in water. Add to pot.
Add potatoes, carrot, sweet potato.
Simmer 30 min until thick and vegetables done.
Serve over rice.

name: Kunu (Millet Drink)
description: Sweet, milky millet drink spiced with ginger and cloves — a Northern Nigerian refresher served cold or at room temperature.
instructions: Soak millet and rice together overnight.
Drain and blend with ginger, cloves, and a little water.
Divide paste into two: mix half with boiling water (to cook it).
Mix the cooked portion back with the raw portion.
Add sugar and more water to desired consistency.
Sieve through a fine mesh.
Chill and serve cold.

name: Ful Medames
description: Slow-simmered fava beans — Egypt's ancient breakfast, eaten for millennia. Drizzled with oil, lemon, and cumin.
instructions: Warm beans in their liquid.
Mash slightly — chunky is traditional.
Season with cumin, garlic, lemon juice, salt.
Drizzle olive oil, sprinkle parsley.
Serve with warm baladi bread, pickles, and vegetables.

name: Ekpang Nkukwo
description: Efik delicacy of grated cocoyam and water yam wrapped in cocoyam leaves, cooked in a spiced palm oil broth.
instructions: Peel and grate cocoyam and water yam separately.
Mix both grated tubers together.
Wrap small portions in cocoyam leaves to form parcels.
Arrange parcels in a pot.
Add palm oil, crayfish, pepper, seasoning, and water.
Add smoked fish and periwinkle between the parcels.
Cook on medium heat for 40–45 minutes until done.
Serve hot directly from the pot.

name: Bogobe (Sorghum Porridge)
description: Traditional Tswana sorghum porridge cooked with melon — a staple accompaniment to seswaa.
instructions: Peel and dice melon. Boil until soft.
Mash the melon in the pot.
Gradually add sorghum meal, stirring constantly.
Cook 20 min on low heat until thick.
Serve with sour milk or alongside seswaa.

name: Dambu Nama (Shredded Meat)
description: Northern Nigerian shredded dried meat — spiced, fluffy, and perfect as a snack or topping.
instructions: Boil beef with onion, garlic, ginger, and seasoning until very tender.
Drain and shred the meat into fine threads using two forks.
Spread shredded meat on a tray. Sun dry for a few hours (or oven dry at 150°F).
Heat oil in a pan. Add the dried shredded meat.
Add yaji spice and toss on low heat for 10 minutes.
The meat should be dry, fluffy, and golden.
Store in an airtight container. Lasts for weeks.

name: Mahshi (Stuffed Vegetables)
description: Egyptian art of stuffed vegetables — grape leaves, cabbage, peppers, and zucchini filled with herbed rice. A labour of love.
ingredients: Grape leaves, cabbage, zucchini, bell peppers
Rice filling: 2 cups rice, tomato, onion, dill, parsley, coriander
instructions: Core zucchini and peppers. Blanch grape leaves and cabbage.
Mix rice with diced tomato, onion, herbs, oil, salt.
Stuff each vegetable. Roll grape leaves and cabbage.
Line pot bottom with extra leaves.
Layer stuffed vegetables tightly.
Add tomato sauce, lemon juice, and water to cover.
Weight with a plate. Cook on low 1 hour.

name: Koklo Meme (Grilled Chicken)
description: Togolese charcoal-grilled chicken marinated in spices — street food at its finest.
instructions: Marinate chicken in lemon, garlic, ginger, chilli, onion, and oil for 1 hour.
Grill over charcoal, turning and basting often.
Cook until charred and cooked through.
Serve with attiéké or fried yam and pepper sauce.

name: Eba and Egusi Soup
description: Nigeria's everyday swallow — garri (cassava flakes) stirred into hot water and eaten with melon seed soup. Quick and filling.
ingredients: Egusi: 1 cup ground melon seeds, spinach or bitter leaf, palm oil, assorted meat, stockfish, crayfish, onion, locust beans, seasoning
instructions: Eba: boil water, add garri, stir quickly until firm.
Fry onion in palm oil. Add locust beans, crayfish.
Dissolve ground egusi. Add to pot. Stir.
Add meat, stockfish. Cook 15 min.
Add chopped spinach. Cook 5 min more.
Serve eba with egusi soup.

name: Taktouka
description: Taktouka (Arabic: تكتوكة) is a traditional Moroccan savory dish and spread made from tomatoes, bell peppers, garlic, toasted paprika and olive oil. Taktouka is an extremely popular dish and can be found in many a restaurant in different parts of Morocco..
tags: articles with self-published sources from april 2025
short description is different from wikidata

name: Ofe Onugbu (Bitter Leaf Soup)
description: Igbo bitter leaf soup — hearty, earthy, and loaded with cocoyam thickener, meat, and stockfish.
instructions: Wash bitter leaves thoroughly until the bitterness reduces. Squeeze dry.
Cook assorted meat, stockfish, and dry fish until tender.
Boil and pound cocoyam into smooth paste (or mix achi with water).
Add palm oil and cocoyam paste to the meat stock. Stir well.
Add ground crayfish, ogiri, and pepper.
Simmer 15 minutes until cocoyam dissolves and soup thickens.
Add the washed bitter leaves. Stir and cook 10 more minutes.
Serve with fufu or garri.

name: Akara (Bean Cakes)
description: Deep-fried bean cakes — crispy outside, fluffy inside. The ultimate Nigerian breakfast, best with pap or bread.
ingredients: 2 cups peeled beans (honey beans or black-eyed peas)
instructions: Soak beans for 1 hour, then rub to remove skins. Rinse.
Blend beans with pepper and onion to a thick, smooth batter. Do NOT add water.
Season with salt. Whisk the batter vigorously to incorporate air (makes it fluffy).
Heat oil in a deep pan to 350°F.
Scoop batter with a spoon and drop into hot oil.
Fry until golden brown on all sides (3–4 minutes).
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with pap (ogi), bread, or garri.

name: Ugali & Sukuma Wiki
description: Kenya's everyday meal — firm maize flour porridge with sautéed collard greens. "Sukuma wiki" means "push the week" (stretch the budget).
instructions: Boil water. Gradually add maize flour, stirring with a wooden spoon.
Stir vigorously until very thick and pulls from the pot.
Cook on low 5 min. Shape into a mound.
For sukuma: fry onion, add tomatoes, then shredded greens.
Cook greens 5 min. Season with salt.
Serve ugali with sukuma wiki.

name: Pondu (Saka Saka)
description: Pounded cassava leaves slow-cooked with palm oil, dried fish, and onion — DRC's beloved leafy stew.
instructions: Pound cassava leaves until very fine. Boil 30 min.
Drain. Transfer to pot with palm oil.
Add soaked dried fish (shredded), onions, tomatoes.
Add water. Simmer on low 30–45 min stirring occasionally.
Season with salt and chilli.
Serve with fufu or rice.

name: Chapati (Kenyan)
description: Kenyan layered flatbread — flakier and richer than Indian version. Everyone's favourite accompaniment.
instructions: Mix flour, salt, sugar. Add warm water and oil.
Knead until smooth. Rest 30 min.
Divide into balls. Roll thin circles.
Brush with oil, fold, and roll again (creates layers).
Cook on a hot pan with oil until golden on both sides.
Stack and keep warm.

name: Babenda
description: Mossi dish of mixed greens cooked with millet flour and soumbala — the quintessential rural Burkinabè meal.
instructions: Boil greens until tender.
Dissolve millet flour in water, add to greens.
Add soumbala for umami flavour.
Stir and simmer until thick porridge.
Serve hot.

name: Mikate (Congolese Doughnuts)
description: Congolese street doughnuts — crispy balls of sweetened dough, perfect with coffee or tea.
instructions: Dissolve yeast in warm water with sugar. Let froth.
Add flour, egg, salt. Mix to thick batter.
Cover, let rise 1 hour until doubled.
Heat oil. Drop spoonfuls of batter into oil.
Fry until golden and puffed (3 min each side).
Drain. Optionally dust with powdered sugar.

name: Fufu & Light Soup
description: Pounded cassava and plantain dough in a spicy tomato-based broth with goat meat or chicken.
instructions: Boil cassava and plantain until very soft.
Pound together in a mortar until smooth and stretchy.
For soup: boil meat with onion and seasoning.
Add blended tomatoes and pepper. Cook 20 min.
Add garden eggs. Simmer until thickened.
Serve fufu in soup bowl.

name: Calulu São-tomense
description: São Tomé's national dish — smoked and fresh fish stewed with okra, tomatoes, and palm oil over slow heat.
instructions: Soak and shred smoked fish.
Layer in pot: onions, tomatoes, okra, aubergine, leaves.
Add both fish on top. Drizzle palm oil.
Add water to just cover.
Cook on low heat 40 min without stirring.
Serve with ângu de banana (mashed starches).

name: Ethiopian Coffee Ceremony
description: More than a drink — a cultural ritual. Beans are roasted, ground, and brewed in a jebena pot. Served three rounds.
instructions: Wash green coffee beans.
Roast beans in a flat pan, shaking until dark and fragrant.
Pass the aromatic beans around for guests to smell.
Grind roasted beans with a mortar and pestle.
Brew in a jebena (clay pot) with water.
Pour from height into small cups (sini).
Serve with sugar and popcorn. Repeat 3 rounds: abol, tona, baraka.

name: Gatsby
description: Massive sub roll stuffed with hot chips, fried polony, atchar, and masala steak — Cape Town's legendary sharing sandwich.
instructions: Fry chips and protein of choice.
Split bread roll lengthwise.
Layer chips, polony/steak, atchar, lettuce.
Sprinkle with vinegar.
Close and wrap in paper.
Cut into sharing portions. Share with mates.

name: Jollof Rice (Ghanaian)
description: Ghana's own jollof — basmati rice cooked in rich tomato sauce with spices. Everyday celebration food and weeknight dinner.
instructions: Blend tomatoes, onion, pepper, ginger, garlic.
Fry remaining onion in oil. Add tomato paste.
Add blended mix. Cook 20 min until oil separates.
Add washed rice, water level with rice.
Add bay leaves, thyme.
Cook on low heat until rice is done.
Serve with shito and fried chicken.

name: Kanda (Meatballs in Sauce)
description: Central African meatballs in tomato-peanut sauce — hearty and flavourful, served with gozo.
instructions: Season ground beef. Form into small balls.
Fry meatballs in oil until browned. Set aside.
Fry onion, garlic. Add tomatoes and pepper.
Dissolve peanut butter in warm water. Add to sauce.
Return meatballs. Simmer 20 min.
Serve over gozo.

name: Cassava Leaf Stew
description: Sierra Leone's staple — finely ground cassava leaves cooked with palm oil, fish, and meat. Rich and earthy.
instructions: Pound or blend cassava leaves very finely.
Boil leaves for 20 min to reduce bitterness.
Cook meat until tender.
In a pot, heat palm oil. Add onion.
Add cassava leaves, meat, fish, and pepper.
Add egusi or groundnut paste for richness.
Simmer 30 min. Serve with rice.

name: Koki Beans
description: Steamed black-eyed pea pudding wrapped in banana leaves with palm oil and crayfish — Cameroon's moi moi.
instructions: Soak and peel beans. Blend smooth.
Add palm oil, pepper, crayfish, and salt to batter.
Optional: add chopped spinach.
Wrap portions in banana leaves, tie securely.
Steam in boiling water for 1 hour.
Unwrap and serve warm.

name: Domoda (Gambian Peanut Stew)
description: The Gambia's national dish — thick, comforting peanut stew with meat and tomato. Ultimate West African comfort.
instructions: Brown meat in oil.
Add onion and tomato paste, fry 5 min.
Add water, peanut paste, and vegetables.
Simmer 40 min, stirring often.
Serve over steamed white rice.

name: Samosa (Kenyan)
description: Crispy triangular pastries stuffed with spiced mince — Kenya's top street snack, influenced by Indian and Arab cuisine.
instructions: Make dough: flour, water, oil, salt. Knead and rest.
Cook filling: fry mince with onion, spices, coriander.
Roll dough thin, cut strips.
Fold into cone, fill, and seal.
Deep fry until golden.

name: Fufu and Light Soup
description: Pounded cassava and plantain with spicy tomato broth and goat or chicken. Ghana's most-eaten evening meal.
ingredients: Soup: whole chicken or goat, tomatoes, onion, pepper, ginger, garden eggs
instructions: Boil cassava and plantain until soft. Pound in pestle until smooth.
Make soup: cook meat until tender.
Add blended tomatoes, onion, pepper, ginger.
Simmer 20 min.
Shape fufu into ball in soup bowl. Ladle soup over.
Eat by tearing fufu and dipping into soup.

name: White Rice and Stew
description: The everyday Nigerian lunch — plain boiled white rice with tomato-pepper stew and fried chicken, beef, or fish. Eaten daily nationwide.
instructions: Boil rice until fluffy. Drain.
Blend tomatoes, peppers. Fry onion in oil.
Add blended pepper. Cook 20 min until oil floats.
Season with salt and seasoning cubes.
Fry or cook protein of choice.
Serve rice with stew and protein.

name: Dambou (Niger)
description: Steamed moringa leaf couscous with groundnuts or oil — Niger's nutritious everyday staple.
instructions: Steam millet couscous until fluffy.
Blanch moringa leaves, chop finely.
Mix moringa into couscous.
Add oil/butter and fried onion.
Season and serve.

name: Indomie Jollof
description: Nigerian-style instant noodles fried with vegetables, egg, and spices — the ultimate student survival meal.
instructions: Boil noodles for 2 minutes. Drain most of the water.
Heat oil in a pan. Fry onion and tomato.
Add diced pepper and optional scotch bonnet.
Add the noodles and seasoning packet. Stir fry.
Push noodles aside. Crack egg into the pan and scramble.
Mix everything together. Serve immediately.

name: Beyaynetu (Ethiopian Fasting Platter)
description: A colourful platter of various lentil, vegetable, and chickpea stews on injera — the ultimate Ethiopian vegan feast.
instructions: Prepare each component separately:
Misir: cook red lentils with berbere and onion.
Gomen: sauté collard greens with garlic.
Shiro: chickpea flour stew as above.
Kik alicha: yellow split peas with turmeric.
Tikil gomen: sauté cabbage, carrot, potato.
Arrange all on a large injera platter.

name: Hawawshi
description: Spiced minced meat stuffed in baladi bread and baked/grilled — Egypt's most beloved quick snack.
instructions: Mix mince with grated onion, pepper, spices, and herbs.
Cut bread pockets open.
Stuff generously with meat mixture.
Brush outside with oil.
Bake at 200°C for 12–15 min until bread is crispy and meat cooked.
Serve hot with pickled vegetables.

name: Kushari
description: Egypt's everyday carb bowl — rice, lentils, macaroni, chickpeas, spicy tomato sauce, and crispy onions layered together.
ingredients: Tomato sauce with vinegar and chilli
instructions: Cook rice, lentils, macaroni separately.
Fry onion rings until crispy dark brown.
Make tomato-vinegar-chilli sauce.
Layer in bowls: rice, lentils, pasta, chickpeas.
Top with sauce and fried onions.

name: Dan Wake
description: Northern Nigerian bean flour dumplings served with pepper sauce and oil — budget-friendly and filling.
ingredients: 1 cup baobab (kuka) powder or cassava flour
instructions: Mix bean flour with kuka powder and a pinch of potash.
Add water gradually and knead into a smooth dough.
Pinch off small lumps and roll into balls.
Boil water in a pot. Drop balls into boiling water.
Cook until they float (about 10 minutes).
Drain and place in a bowl.
Drizzle with oil and pepper sauce. Add sliced onions.
Serve warm.

name: Egusi Soup
description: Rich melon-seed soup with leafy greens, assorted meat, and stockfish. The most popular soup across Nigeria.
ingredients: 500 g assorted meat (beef, tripe, cow skin)
3 cups chopped spinach or bitter leaf
instructions: Boil assorted meat with onion, seasoning cubes, and salt until tender. Reserve stock.
Heat palm oil in a pot (do not bleach).
Add diced onion and fry until translucent.
Mix ground egusi with a little water to form a thick paste.
Add egusi paste to oil in lumps. Fry for 5 minutes, stirring gently.
Pour in reserved meat stock gradually. Stir well.
Add ground crayfish, scotch bonnets, and cooked meat.
Simmer for 15 minutes on medium heat.
Add chopped spinach or washed bitter leaf. Cook 5 more minutes.
Adjust seasoning and serve with pounded yam, eba, or fufu.

name: Dovi (Peanut Butter Stew)
description: Zimbabwe's peanut butter chicken stew — creamy, rich, and served over sadza. A national favourite.
instructions: Brown chicken in oil. Remove.
Fry onions and garlic. Add chopped tomatoes.
Dissolve peanut butter in warm water. Add to pot.
Return chicken. Simmer 30 min until cooked through.
Sauce should be thick and creamy.
Serve over sadza with greens.

name: Ewa Agoyin (Mashed Beans)
description: Soft, mashed honey beans drenched in fiery dried pepper sauce — a Yoruba street food legend.
instructions: Boil beans until very soft and mashable.
Mash lightly with a wooden spoon (keep some texture).
For the sauce: bleach palm oil until clear.
Blend dried peppers and bell peppers.
Fry onions in the oil until blackened.
Add blended peppers and crayfish. Fry until oil floats.
Pour sauce generously over mashed beans.
Serve with bread or fried plantain.

name: Bariis Iskukaris (Somali Spiced Rice)
description: Somali fragrant rice with meat — spiced with cumin, cardamom, and cinnamon. Every Somali household's pride.
instructions: Cook meat with spices until tender.
Fry onions until golden, add tomato paste.
Add rice, meat broth, and potatoes.
Sprinkle raisins on top.
Cook covered on low heat until rice is fluffy.

name: Koeksister
description: Braided dough deep-fried and dunked in cold syrup — crunchy, dripping sweet, and addictive.
ingredients: Syrup: 3 cups sugar, 1.5 cups water, 1 tsp cream of tartar, 1 stick cinnamon, 1 tsp ginger
instructions: Make syrup: boil sugar, water, cream of tartar, spices. Chill overnight.
Mix flour, baking powder, salt. Rub in butter.
Add egg and milk. Knead lightly.
Roll out, cut strips, braid into twists.
Deep fry until golden (2 min each side).
Drop hot koeksisters straight into ice-cold syrup.
Remove, drain. Serve immediately for max crunch.

name: Succotash de Mariscos
description: Equatoguinean seafood stew — prawns, fish, and vegetables in a peppery tomato broth. Spanish-African fusion.
instructions: Fry onion and garlic in palm oil.
Add tomatoes, peppers, chilli. Cook 10 min.
Add fish and plantain. Simmer 10 min.
Add prawns last 5 min.
Season well.
Serve with rice or boiled plantain.

name: Masa (Waina)
description: Northern Nigerian rice cakes — slightly sour, spongy, and fried in a special round mould. Served with sugar, honey, or pepper soup.
instructions: Soak rice overnight. Drain.
Blend soaked rice with cooked rice and a little water to a smooth batter.
Add yeast and sugar. Mix well.
Cover and ferment for 6–8 hours (overnight is best).
When bubbly and slightly sour, add salt.
Heat a masa pan (or aebleskiver pan) with oil.
Pour batter into each mould. Cover and cook until set.
Flip and cook the other side until golden.
Serve with sugar, honey, or pepper soup.

name: Ofe Oha
description: Traditional Igbo soup made with tender oha leaves, cocoyam, and assorted proteins — fragrant and earthy.
instructions: Cook assorted meat with stockfish until tender. Reserve stock.
Prepare cocoyam paste by boiling and pounding cocoyam.
Add palm oil and cocoyam to the stock. Stir to dissolve.
Add crayfish, ogiri, pepper, and seasoning. Simmer 15 minutes.
When soup thickens, add meat and fish.
Shred oha leaves by hand (do not cut with knife) and stir in.
Cook 5 minutes. Do not overcook the leaves.
Serve with fufu, eba, or pounded yam.

name: Matoke (Steamed Green Banana)
description: Uganda's national dish — steamed green bananas mashed and served with peanut sauce, meat, or bean stew.
instructions: Peel green bananas.
Wrap in banana leaves.
Steam in a pot for 30 min until very soft.
Mash inside the leaves until smooth.
Serve with groundnut sauce, beef stew, or beans.

name: Tigadèguèna (Mali Peanut Stew)
description: Mali's beloved peanut butter stew — rich, thick, and served over rice. The country's most iconic home-cooked meal.
instructions: Brown meat with onions in oil.
Add chopped tomatoes, cook 10 min.
Dissolve peanut butter in warm water, add to pot.
Add sweet potato and okra.
Simmer 35 min until thick.
Serve over steamed rice.

name: Zobo (Hibiscus Drink)
description: Deep-red hibiscus flower drink — sweet, tart, and spiced with ginger and cloves. Nigeria's favourite homemade juice.
instructions: Rinse zobo leaves to remove dirt.
Add to a pot with water, ginger, cloves, and cinnamon.
Boil for 20–30 minutes until deep red.
Strain into a large jug.
Blend pineapple and strain the juice into the zobo.
Add sugar or honey to taste.
Refrigerate until ice cold.
Serve over ice. Add diced fruit for garnish.

name: Beans and Plantain
description: Boiled or porridge beans with fried ripe plantain — the ultimate Nigerian comfort combo. Budget king.
instructions: Cook beans until tender (parboil first if needed).
Add palm oil, diced onion, pepper, crayfish, salt.
Cook until porridge-like or leave whole beans.
Slice ripe plantain diagonally. Fry until golden.
Serve beans with fried plantain on the side.

name: Makala (Congolese Doughnut)
description: Congolese fried dough — denser and more fragrant than puff puff. Sold in bags at markets across Kinshasa.
instructions: Mix flour, sugar, yeast, vanilla, mashed banana.
Add warm water to form thick batter.
Cover and rise 1 hour.
Drop spoonfuls into hot oil.
Fry until golden.
Drain and serve in paper bags.

name: Bâton de Manioc
description: Fermented cassava wrapped in banana leaves and steamed — Gabon and Central Africa's essential starchy side.
instructions: Soak cassava in water 3 days to ferment.
Grate and press out liquid.
Wrap portions in softened banana leaves into sticks.
Tie with raffia or string.
Steam for 30 min.
Serve alongside any stew or grilled meat.

name: Moroccan Mint Tea
description: Moroccan hospitality in a glass — Chinese gunpowder green tea with fresh mint and a LOT of sugar. Poured from height.
instructions: Add tea to teapot. Pour in boiling water, swirl and discard (rinse).
Add fresh mint leaves and sugar.
Add boiling water. Steep 3–5 min.
Pour a glass and return to pot (wake the tea) 2–3 times.
Serve by pouring from height to create foam.
Serve 3 glasses as tradition.

name: Matapa
description: Cassava leaf stew cooked with peanuts, coconut milk, and garlic. Mozambique's everyday green dish.
instructions: Boil pounded cassava leaves for 20 min.
Add peanut butter dissolved in coconut milk.
Add garlic. Stir.
Simmer 15 min until thick.
Serve with rice or xima.

name: Couscous Tunisien
description: Tunisian spicy couscous — unlike Moroccan, it's fiery red from harissa, served with lamb and vegetables.
instructions: Cook meat with onion, tomato paste, harissa, and spices in water.
Add vegetables in stages.
Steam couscous over the stew 2–3 times.
Fluff with olive oil.
Serve couscous mounded with stew on top.

name: Moi Moi and Custard/Pap
description: Steamed bean pudding paired with smooth pap/custard — a popular Nigerian breakfast or light dinner combo.
ingredients: Moi Moi: 3 cups peeled beans, peppers, onion, palm oil, eggs, fish, crayfish, seasoning
Pap: fermented corn paste, water, sugar, milk
instructions: Blend beans with peppers, onion. Season.
Add palm oil, crayfish, eggs, fish.
Wrap in leaves or foil. Steam 45 min.
Make pap: dissolve paste in cold water, pour into boiling water.
Stir until set. Add sugar and milk.
Serve moi moi with a bowl of warm pap.

name: Café Touba
description:
Café Touba is a coffee beverage that is a popular traditional drink from Senegal that is (more recently) also consumed in Guinea-Bissau, and is named for the city of Touba, Senegal.
Café Touba is a coffee drink that is flavored with grains of Selim or Guinea pepper (the dried fruit of the shrub Xylopia aethiopica) (locally known as djar, in the Wolof language) and sometimes cloves. The addition of djar, that is cultivated in  Touba, is the important factor differentiating café Touba from plain coffee. The spices are mixed and roasted with coffee beans, then ground into a powder.

name: Umm Ali (Egyptian Bread Pudding)
description: Egypt's legendary dessert — layers of puff pastry soaked in milk and cream with raisins, nuts, and coconut.
instructions: Bake puff pastry until golden. Break into pieces.
Layer pastry in a baking dish with nuts, raisins, and coconut.
Heat milk with sugar and vanilla.
Pour hot milk over pastry.
Spoon cream on top.
Broil until golden and bubbly.
Serve warm.

name: Efo Riro
description: Yoruba-style rich vegetable soup made with assorted meats, locust beans, and a luscious palm oil base.
ingredients: 1 large bunch spinach (efo tete or shoko)
instructions: Cook assorted meat until tender. Reserve stock.
Blanch spinach in boiling water for 1 minute. Drain and set aside.
Heat palm oil, fry onions until golden.
Add blended peppers and cook until oil floats on top.
Add locust beans, crayfish, and seasoning.
Pour in meat stock and add cooked meat/fish.
Simmer for 10 minutes.
Fold in the blanched vegetables. Cook 3–5 minutes.
Serve hot with amala, pounded yam, or eba.

name: Nshima, Kapenta and Chibwabwa
description: Zambia's triple combo — nshima porridge with tiny dried kapenta fish and pumpkin leaf relish.
ingredients: Kapenta: 1 cup dried kapenta, tomato, onion, oil
Chibwabwa: 1 bunch pumpkin leaves, peanut powder, tomato
instructions: Make nshima: boil water, add mealie meal, cook 20 min.
Fry kapenta with onion and tomato.
Boil pumpkin leaves. Add peanut powder and tomato.
Serve nshima with kapenta and chibwabwa.

name: Garba (Attiéké with Tuna)
description: Street food legend — attiéké served with fried tuna, chilli, and onions. Named after a person who popularized it.
ingredients: Canned tuna or fried tuna steaks
instructions: Steam or fluff attiéké.
If using fresh tuna, season and fry in oil.
Mix onion, tomato, pepper, oil, and seasoning for sauce.
Serve attiéké with tuna and sauce on top.

name: Biltong
description: Air-dried cured meat — South Africa's beloved snack, miles ahead of jerky. Beef, kudu, or ostrich.
instructions: Cut meat into long strips (2 cm thick) along the grain.
Mix salt, coriander, pepper, sugar, bicarb.
Dip strips in vinegar, then coat in spice mix.
Layer in a container, refrigerate 12–24 hours.
Pat dry, hang in a biltong box or dryer.
Dry for 3–5 days depending on thickness.
Slice thin for dry or thick for wet biltong.

name: Fried Rice (Nigerian)
description: Nigerian party-style fried rice — basmati rice stir-fried with mixed vegetables, liver, prawns, and curry. Sunday special.
ingredients: Mixed vegetables (carrots, green beans, peas, sweetcorn)
instructions: Boil rice until almost done. Drain.
Dice and blanch vegetables.
Scramble eggs separately. Set aside.
Heat oil. Add rice and vegetables.
Add curry, thyme, soy sauce.
Stir-fry 5 min. Add egg and liver.
Serve with grilled chicken and coleslaw.

name: Harira
description: Tomato-lentil-chickpea soup — Morocco's daily dinner and the traditional Ramadan iftar soup. Thick, hearty, and warming.
instructions: Brown meat with onion, spices.
Add tomatoes, celery, herbs. Cover with water.
Simmer 30 min.
Add lentils and chickpeas. Cook 20 min more.
Thicken with flour-water mixture.
Serve with dates and chebakia (honey pastry).

name: Injera with Doro Wat
description: Ethiopia's festive dish — spicy chicken stew with hard-boiled eggs on sourdough injera. Quintessential Ethiopian cuisine.
instructions: Dry-fry diced onions (no oil) stirring 20 min until browned and sweet.
Add niter kibbeh, garlic, and ginger. Cook 5 min.
Add berbere and tomato paste. Stir 10 min.
Add chicken pieces. Cook in sauce 45 min adding water as needed.
Score hard-boiled eggs and add to stew last 15 min.
Serve on a large injera, with rolled injera for scooping.

name: Muamba de Galinha
description: Angola's national dish — chicken stew in palm oil with okra, squash, and garlic. Rich and hearty.
instructions: Season chicken with garlic, lemon, salt. Marinate 30 min.
Fry chicken in palm oil until browned.
Add onions and tomatoes. Cook 10 min.
Add squash and water. Simmer 25 min.
Add okra last 10 min.
Serve with funge (cassava porridge) or rice.

name: Rolex (Rolled Eggs)
description: Uganda's iconic street food — a chapati rolled around an omelette with cabbage and tomato. "Rolled eggs" → Rolex!
instructions: Cook chapati on a flat pan with oil.
Beat eggs with diced onion, cabbage, and tomato.
Pour egg mixture on pan, place chapati on top.
Flip when egg is set.
Roll chapati around the omelette.
Serve immediately — Uganda's best street food.

name: Shawarma (Egyptian Style)
description: Egyptian shawarma — thinly sliced marinated chicken or beef wrapped in bread with tahini, pickles, and garlic paste.
instructions: Marinate meat in yogurt and spices for 2+ hours.
Cook meat in batches on a very hot pan or grill.
Slice thin.
Warm bread. Spread with garlic paste and tahini.
Add meat, pickles, tomato, and onion.
Roll tight and grill the wrap.

name: Bole (Roasted Plantain)
description: Ripe plantain roasted whole over charcoal until caramelised and smoky. Served with roasted groundnuts or pepper sauce. Port Harcourt signature.
ingredients: Pepper sauce: scotch bonnet, palm oil, onion
instructions: Place whole unpeeled ripe plantains on charcoal grill.
Turn every 3–4 min until skin is blackened and flesh soft.
Peel. Serve with roasted groundnuts.
Or serve with spicy palm oil pepper sauce.

name: Mishkaki
description: Marinated beef skewers grilled over charcoal — Tanzania's beloved street barbecue. Swahili-spiced perfection.
instructions: Cube beef. Marinate in lemon, garlic, ginger, cumin, coriander, chilli, oil.
Rest 1 hour minimum.
Thread onto skewers.
Grill over charcoal, basting with marinade.
Serve with chilli sauce and naan or chips.

name: Coconut Rice
description: Fragrant, creamy rice cooked in coconut milk — a Southern Nigerian twist on everyday rice.
instructions: Parboil rice until half done. Drain.
Blend pepper and onion.
Fry blended pepper in oil until reduced.
Add coconut milk and water. Bring to a boil.
Add rice, curry, seasoning, and salt.
Cover tightly and cook on low heat until rice absorbs all liquid.
Fluff and serve with fried plantain or chicken.

name: Banku & Tilapia
description: Fermented corn and cassava dough served with grilled tilapia and hot pepper sauce — a Ga classic.
instructions: Mix corn dough and cassava dough with water.
Cook on medium heat, stirring continuously with a wooden spoon.
Stir vigorously until smooth, thick, and pulls away from pot.
Mould into balls.
Season and grill tilapia over charcoal.
Serve with hot pepper sauce.

name: Vary amin'anana (Rice and Greens)
description: Madagascar's everyday combo — rice cooked with mixed leafy greens, garlic, and ginger. Simple and nutritious.
instructions: Fry garlic and ginger in oil.
Add chopped greens. Cook 3 min.
Add rice and water.
Cook until rice is done and absorbed the green colour.
Serve as a complete light meal.

name: Dodo (Fried Plantain)
description: Sweet, caramelized fried ripe plantain slices — the side dish that makes every Nigerian meal better.
instructions: Peel plantains and slice diagonally (about 1 cm thick).
Heat oil in a frying pan.
Fry plantain slices on medium heat until golden brown on each side.
Remove and drain on paper towels.
Serve alongside rice, beans, or as a standalone snack.

name: Makande (Maize and Beans)
description: Boiled maize and kidney beans — Tanzania's cheap everyday sustenance. Similar to Kenya's githeri.
instructions: Soak maize and beans overnight.
Boil until both are tender (1 hr).
Fry onion and tomatoes.
Add to maize and beans.
Add coconut milk for creaminess (coastal style).
Serve hot.

name: Achu Soup and Fufu (Yellow Soup)
description: Northwest Cameroon combo — pounded cocoyam (achu) with spicy yellow palm oil soup (kanwa).
ingredients: Yellow soup: limestone paste (kanwa), palm oil, spices, meat stock
Assorted meat: tripe, cow skin, beef
instructions: Boil and pound cocoyam until smooth and stretchy.
Shape into balls.
Dissolve kanwa in warm water. Mix with red palm oil (turns yellow).
Add spiced meat stock. Simmer.
Serve achu ball in a bowl. Ladle yellow soup around it.
Add boiled meat pieces.

name: Cambuulo (Adzuki Bean Dessert)
description: Somali slow-cooked adzuki beans with butter and sugar — a sweet, hearty dish often eaten at night.
instructions: Soak beans overnight.
Boil until very soft (2+ hours).
Mash slightly.
Mix in butter and sugar.
Serve warm or at room temperature.

name: Yassa Poulet
description: Chicken marinated in lemon and onion then braised — Senegal's everyday chicken and rice dinner. Casamance origin.
instructions: Marinate chicken in lemon juice, onion, mustard, garlic (1 hr minimum).
Grill or fry chicken until golden.
Fry marinated onions slowly until caramelised.
Add chicken back, olives. Simmer 20 min.
Serve over steamed white rice.

name: Nsima with Chambo
description: Malawi's pride — nsima (maize porridge) with grilled chambo fish from Lake Malawi. Nation's favourite meal.
instructions: Make nsima: boil water, add maize flour, stir 20 min.
Season fish with salt and lemon. Score the sides.
Grill over charcoal until cooked through.
Make relish: fry onion, add tomatoes. Season.
Serve nsima with grilled chambo and tomato relish.

name: Tajine Zitoun
description: Tajine Zitoun or Tajine El Zitoune (Arabic: طاجين الزيتون) or Tagine Zitoune or Olive Tajine is a traditional Algerian stew from the city of Algiers. It is named after the earthenware pot in which it is cooked, a tajine pot. Tajine zitoun typically includes lamb, turkey or chicken and olives as the main ingredient, often also with some combination of onions, carrots, mushrooms or other vegetables, and is often seasoned with thyme, bay leaves, lemon juice, and saffron or turmeric.
